title: Question 2
content:
Which of the following systems represents a homogeneous mixture?


- A.$\hspace{1.em}$Oil floating on water
- B.$\hspace{1.em}$Salt dissolved in water at $25{\,}^\circ\textrm{C}$
- C.$\hspace{1.em}$Ice cubes in liquid water
- D.$\hspace{1.em}$Sand mixed with iron filings
markScheme:
B

$\textrm{\underline{Explanation:}}$
A homogeneous mixture has uniform composition and properties throughout, with components mixed at the molecular level. Salt dissolved in water forms a solution where sodium and chloride ions are uniformly distributed among water molecules, creating a single phase with consistent properties. Oil and water form separate layers (heterogeneous), ice and liquid water exist as different phases (heterogeneous), and sand with iron filings shows visible distinct components (heterogeneous). The key distinction is whether the mixture appears uniform at the molecular level.

title: Question 3
content:
Which of the following is an example of a mixture?


- A.$\hspace{1em}$Sucrose
- B.$\hspace{1em}$Distilled water
- C.$\hspace{1em}$Seawater
- D.$\hspace{1em}$Sodium chloride
markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Seawater is a mixture of water and salts. Sucrose, distilled water, and sodium chloride are all examples of compounds.

title: Question 4
content:
Which of the following is a characteristic of liquids?


- A.$\hspace{1em}$Their particles vibrate about fixed positions.
- B.$\hspace{1em}$They can be compressed easily.
- C.$\hspace{1em}$They take up the shape of the container they are in.
- D.$\hspace{1em}$The particles move freely and quickly in all directions.
markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:  
Liquids have an indefinite shape (take the shape of the container) but have a definite volume (are incompressible).

title: Question 6
content:
A liquid has a boiling point of $-185 ^\circ\mathrm{C}$. What is this temperature in Kelvin?


- A.$\hspace{1em}$88 K
- B.$\hspace{1em}-88$ K
- C.$\hspace{1em}$458 K
- D.$\hspace{1em}-458$ K
markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Add $273$ to the temperature in Celsius to convert it to Kelvin.
$-185^\circ\mathrm{C} + 273 = \answer{88\, \textrm{K}}$
$\ $

title: Question 7
content:
Which of the following requires a chemical reaction to be separated into simpler substances?


- A. $\hspace{1em}$Homogeneous mixtures
- B. $\hspace{1em}$Heterogeneous mixtures
- C. $\hspace{1em}$Alloys
- D. $\hspace{1em}$Compounds
markScheme:
D

$\textrm{\underline{Explanation:}}$
Mixtures, including alloys, can be separated by physical methods like filtration, evaporation, or distillation. Compounds must be chemically separated.

title: Question 9
content:
Which of the following statements correctly describes a compound?


- I.A compound can be physically separated into simpler substances.II.In a pure compound, the boiling point, melting point and solubility are uniform.III.Each compound has a fixed chemical formula in which the subscripts remain constant.



- A. $\hspace{1em}$I and II only
- B. $\hspace{1em}$I and III only
- C. $\hspace{1em}$II and III only
- D. $\hspace{1em}$I, II and III
markScheme:
C

$\textrm{\underline{Explanation:}}$
Statement I is incorrect because compounds cannot be broken down by physical means, only by chemical reactions. Statement II is correct because compounds have fixed physical properties (boiling point, melting point, solubility) due to their uniform composition. Statement III is correct because compounds obey the Law of Definite Proportions, they have fixed chemical formulas where the subscripts do not change (e.g., $\ce{H2O}$ is always water).

title: Question 10
content: [Maximum marks: 7] Crude oil (also known as petroleum) is a homogeneous mixture of volatile liquid hydrocarbons. Before it can be used, it must be refined to separate it into simpler, more useful mixtures. - Describe a homogeneous mixture. [1] - Contrast the microscopic structure and behavior of liquids and gases using the kinetic molecular theory. [2] - State the physical property of the components of crude oil that allows them to be separated by fractional distillation. [1] - Kerosene, a fuel used in aviation, is one of the fractions obtained from crude oil. $\newline \ \newline$ - Kerosene has a boiling point of 240.00Â°C. Convert this temperature to Kelvin using Section 1 of the IB Chemistry Data Booklet. [1] - Explain, using the kinetic molecular theory, why kerosene vaporizes when heated. [2]
markScheme:
- uniform composition /  single$-$phase of physically$-$combined components / two or more different elements or compounds not in fixed ratios / components not chemically bonded  $\checkmark$
  $\textrm{\underline{Further Explanation:}}$
A homogeneous mixture is one in which the composition is uniform throughout, meaning the individual components are evenly distributed and cannot be distinguished by simple observation. They appear as a single phase. Unlike compounds, the substances within a homogeneous mixture are not chemically bonded, so they retain their original chemical properties and they can combine in any ratio since they do not obey the Law of Definite Proportions.
- Any two of:
  
  
  - liquid particles are close together while gas particles are far apart $\checkmark$
  - liquid particles experience intermolecular /interatomic forces while gas particles do not $\checkmark$
  - liquids are not compressible while gases are very compressible $\checkmark$
  - liquids have a fixed volume while gases expand to fill a container $\checkmark$

  $\textrm{\underline{Further Explanation:}}$
The particles in a liquid move freely, sliding past each other in a closely$-$packed but disordered structure.  This allows a liquid to change its shape to fit its container while maintaining a fixed volume.  Since the particles remain in close contact, liquids are not compressible.  The particles do experience attractions to one aonther (intermolecular / interatomic forces) that must be overcome to enter into the gas phase.
  The particles in a gas are in constant random motion, moving rabidly in all directions with negligible forces between them.  The particles are far apart, allowing gases to expand to fill their container and making them highly compressible.
  $\\ \newline \\$
- Different boiling points/volatility $\checkmark$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}$
The components of crude oil can be separated by fractional distillation because they have different boiling points. When crude oil is heated, the hydrocarbons with the lowest boiling points evaporate first, while those with higher boiling points remain in liquid form until reaching their respective boiling temperatures.  The fractions that are removed from the sample are groups of similarly sized hydrocarbons.
- 
  - $240.00+273.15 = 513.15 \textrm{\ K}\:\checkmark$
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}$
The Kelvin scale is shifted from the Celsius scale to place the 0 at absolute zero instead of the freezing point of water:
    Temperature (K) = Temperature ($^\circ$C) + 273.15
  - kinetic energy  increases, molecules move faster $\checkmark$ 
boils when molecules have enough energy to overcome intermolecular forces, and transition from liquid to gas $\checkmark$
    $\textrm{\underline{Further Explanation:}}$
According to the kinetic molecular theory, the temperature of a substance is directly related to the average kinetic energy of its particles. As kerosene is heated, its molecules absorb energy and move faster, increasing their kinetic energy. At the boiling point, the molecules have gained enough energy to break the intermolecular forces that hold them in the liquid state. This allows them to escape as into the gas phase, leading to vaporization.

title: Question 13
content:
Which of the following statements about liquids is correct?


- A.$\hspace{1em}$They can be compressed and undergo an endothermic process to vaporize.
- B.$\hspace{1em}$They cannot be compressed and undergo an endothermic process to vaporize.
- C.$\hspace{1em}$They can be compressed and undergo an exothermic process to vaporize.
- D.$\hspace{1em}$They cannot be compressed and undergo an exothermic process to vaporize.
markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
According to the kinetic molecular theory, particles in a liquid are close together and held by intermolecular forces, which gives a liquid a fixed volume. However, these particles can move past one another, so a liquid does not have a fixed shape. Because the particles are already close together, liquids are nearly incompressible.
Liquids can also change to the gas state when enough energy is supplied to overcome the intermolecular attractions. This process of vaporization is endothermic, as energy from the surroundings is absorbed to separate the particles further apart.
This question is of medium difficulty, as students must recall the properties of liquids and link them to the energy changes involved in changes of state.

title: Question 16
content:
Sugar must be recovered from a solution of sugar and ethanol. Which statement(s) below is(are) correct?
Hint: Ethanol is highly flammable with a boiling point of 78$\,{}^\circ$C.


- I.$\hspace{1.em}$Evaporation with a Bunsen burner is appropriate.
- II.$\hspace{0.7em}$A hot water bath (above $78\,{}^\circ\text{C}$) can be used with an evaporating basin containing the mixture.
- III.$\hspace{0.4em}$Filtration is safe and appropriate for this separation.



- A.$\hspace{1em}$I only
- B.$\hspace{1em}$II only
- C.$\hspace{1em}$III only
- D.$\hspace{1em}$I and II only
markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Ethanol is highly flammable so direct heating with a Bunsen burner is unsafe. Statement I is incorrect.
The correct method is to use a hot water bath at a temperature above ethanol's boiling point. This allows ethanol to evaporate safely, leaving solid sugar in the evaporating basin. Statement II is correct.
Filtration cannot separate sugar dissolved in ethanol, since both pass through the filter paper. Statement III is therefore incorrect.
This question is of medium difficulty, as it requires understanding both the practical safety concerns of laboratory techniques and the limitations of separation methods.

title: Question 18
content:
Consider the cooling curve of ethanol below which shows the temperature change as heat is removed at a constant rate.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/82172fd2-c4d0-4e78-b06f-3acc44195dc3/images/6d132a89-2951-40e2-bf6d-97c13f23c472/CH1220.png)


Which statement is correct about ethanol?


- A.$\hspace{1em}$Condensation takes longer than freezing as more heat is needed for this physical change.
- B.$\hspace{1em}$Condensation takes longer than freezing as more heat must be removed for this physical change.
- C.$\hspace{1em}$Sublimation occurs at $78{}^\circ\text{C}.$
- D.$\hspace{1em}$Deposition occurs at $-114{}^\circ\text{C}.$
markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
A cooling curve tracks how a substance loses energy as temperature decreases. The sloped regions show cooling within a phase, where particles lose kinetic energy and the temperature falls. The flat regions represent phase changes, when temperature remains constant because the energy released is due to intermolecular forces being formed.
The long plateau near $78^\circ\text{C}$ corresponds to condensation. Gas particles must come close together and form many new intermolecular forces, releasing a large quantity of energy to the surroundings. The shorter plateau near $-114^\circ\text{C}$ corresponds to freezing, where fewer forces are formed as the liquid arranges into the solid structure, so less energy is released.  Condensation takes longer than freezing as more heat must be removed.
Only condensation and freezing are represented here. Sublimation (solid to gas) or deposition (gas to solid) do not occur under these conditions and are not shown.

title: Question 19
content:
Which of the following correctly describes the properties of a homogeneous mixture?


- A. $\hspace{1em}$The physical properties are uniform and the chemical properties of its components remain unchanged.
- B. $\hspace{1em}$The physical and chemical properties are those of its most abundant component.
- C. $\hspace{1em}$The physical and chemical properties are an average of the properties of its components.
- D. $\hspace{1em}$The physical properties vary throughout the sample, and its components do not retain their chemical properties.
markScheme:
A

$\textrm{\underline{Explanation:}}$
A homogeneous mixture is one in which the composition and physical properties are uniform throughout the sample, and the chemical identity of each component remains unchanged.
Unlike a pure substance, a mixture's physical properties depend on the proportions and interactions of its components rather than on its most abundant component or a simple average.  Salt water is conductive while both pure water liquid and pure sodium chloride crystals are not.  Solder, a common alloy of tin and lead used in electronics, has a melting point of $183^\circ\text{C}$ while lead melts at 327$^\circ\text{C}$ and tin melts at 232$^\circ\text{C}.$ Again, solder does not take on the properties of the more abundant tin or have a melting point that is the average of its components.

title: Question 20
content: Plant pigments were analyzed through paper chromatography. Standards A, B, C and D were eluted next to three plant extracts: X, Y, and Z. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/041cf040-4592-491d-9395-7a0e393f941b/images/99bb5999-c89e-494b-bd48-66be00a32111/CH1105.png) A group of students analyzed the results. Their hypotheses are listed below: - Mariana: Plant Z contains pigments B and C, and it is a mixture of only three components. - Hiba: Plant Y contains pigments A and D. All three plants contain a mixture of pigments. - Priya: Plant X has many colored components. The component marked $\textbf{s}$ has the lowest retention factor. - Comment on the validity of each hypothesis. [3] - Calculate the retention factor, $R_f,$ of the spot $\textbf{s}$ in standard A. [1] - Identify the standard with the lowest affinity for the solvent. Explain your reasoning. [2] - Suggest one limitation of paper chromatography as a separating technique. [1]
markScheme:
- Mariana: incorrect, chromatogram shows $\underline{\textrm{at least}}$ three components (including B and C) $\checkmark$
Hiba:  correct, all plant pigments resolve into more than one spot $\checkmark$ 
Priya: incorrect, spot $s$ has the highest retention factor $\checkmark$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further explanation}}$:
Mariana's hypothesis is incorrect. Plant Z contains standards B and C as the spots in B and C are detected. However, separation into three spots does not prove to be a mixture of three components only. Some of these spots could be mixtures of unseparated components. We can say that plant Z is a mixture of at least three components.
  Hiba's hypothesis is correct as plant Y includes the pigments detected in standards A and D. In addition, it is true that all these plants (X, Y, and Z) are made of a mixture of pigments as different spots have been detected in all of them.
  Priya's hypothesis is incorrect. Plant X has many colored components. However, the spot $\textbf{s}$ has the highest retention factor compared to the other spots.
- $R_f = \dfrac{4.2 \textrm{\ cm} -0.5\,\text{cm}}{4.5 \textrm{\ cm}-0.5\,\text{cm}} = 0.93\,\checkmark$
Accept any value between 0.90 and 0.95.
  $\underline{\textrm{Further explanation:}}$
Using the relationship for the retention factor
  $R_f = \dfrac{\text{distance traveled by the spot}}{\text{distance traveled by the solvent front}}$
  and the measured the position of the starting line, 0.5 cm, the spot, 4.2 cm, and the solvent front, 4.5 cm; the retention factor can be calculated.
- Standard C $\checkmark$
smallest $R_f$ factor: high affinity for stationary phase and low affinity for mobile phase $\checkmark$
- Any of the following:
  
  
  - works for colored components or requires visualization technique (UV / ninhydrin / iodine) $\checkmark$
  - separation might be incomplete / spots can be mixtures of components with similar $R_f$ $\checkmark$
  - only allows the separation of a small amount of sample $\checkmark$
  - time$-$consuming technique $\checkmark$
  - spot centers can be difficult to estimate, $R_f$ has high random error $\checkmark$
  - other reasonable answers $\checkmark$

title: Question 22
content: The melting point of benzene is $5.5\,{}^\circ\text{C}$, and its boiling point is $80.1\,{}^\circ\text{C}.$ - Draw the heating curve for benzene from $-10\,{}^\circ\text{C}$ to $110\,{}^\circ\text{C}.$ [3] - State the state of matter of benzene at $-6.0\,{}^\circ\text{C}.$ [1] - Describe the arrangement of benzene molecules at $50.0\,{}^\circ\text{C}.$ [2] - $5.00\,\text{g}$ of $\ce{NaCl}$ is added to $100\,\text{cm}^3$ of benzene. The salt is insoluble in the solvent. - Determine the type of mixture formed. [1] - Suggest a technique that can be applied to separate and recover benzene and sodium chloride. Sketch a labeled diagram to show how the separation will take place. [4]
markScheme:
- Temperature must be on the vertical axis and time on the horizontal axis; $\checkmark$
  Positive gradient from $-10.0\,{}^\circ\text{C}$ until $5.5\,{}^\circ\text{C}$ and a flat section at $5.5\,{}^\circ\text{C}$; $\checkmark$
  Positive gradient from $5.5\,{}^\circ\text{C}$ until $80.1\,{}^\circ\text{C}$ and a flat section at $80.1\,{}^\circ\text{C}$ and positive gradient beyond $80.1\,{}^\circ\text{C}$; $\checkmark$
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/0e57860c-f4b3-4176-a0c6-7930fe46fdbe/images/fade02e5-06aa-4f09-b207-713810d89393/keep.png)


$\footnotesize{\textrm{[Â© Revision Village 2023.]}}$
- solid. $\checkmark$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$:
  $-6.0\,{}^\circ\text{C}$ is below $5.5\,{}^\circ\text{C}$ (below the melting point).
- Any 2 of the following:
  Molecules close to one another (not in a regular pattern); $\checkmark$
  Molecules vibrating, rotating, and moving around; $\checkmark$
  Molecules can slide over each other. $\checkmark$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$:
  At $50.0\,{}^\circ\text{C}$, benzene is above the melting point ($5.5\,{}^\circ\text{C}$) and below the boiling point ($80.1\,{}^\circ\text{C}).$ Benzene is in the liquid state.
- 
  - Heterogeneous mixture. $\checkmark$
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$:
    Sodium chloride is insoluble in benzene. The solid remains undissolved as a separate phase, and particles are not evenly distributed throughout the mixture.
  - Filtration. $\checkmark$
    ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/0e57860c-f4b3-4176-a0c6-7930fe46fdbe/images/ee3fa417-9a36-439f-a815-0640036d5eb9/unnamed.png)


$\footnotesize{\textrm{[Â© Revision Village 2023. Created with Chemix (https://chemix.org)]}}$
    A funnel with filtering paper must be shown in the sketch; $\checkmark$
    Sodium chloride/residue in the filtering paper; $\checkmark$
    Benzene/filtrate shown. $\checkmark$
    $\underline{\textrm{Further explanation}}$:
    Sodium chloride is insoluble, and filtration allows the separation of a solid from a liquid by pouring the mixture through a paper filter. The solid is collected in the paper filter (residue), and the liquid goes through to be collected below (filtrate).

title: Question 23
content: The diagram below represents the heating of ice starting at $-20\, {}^\circ \mathrm{C}$. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/1f51d593-8291-47ae-b2c8-aeac004505c4/images/d3ea81a7-8121-4008-b366-171141838e4e/CH0013.png) - Complete the table. [5] Segment numberWhat phase(s) is/are present?What is happening at the particle level?What phase change, if any, is taking place?12345 $\ \mbox{}\\[-20pts]$ - Give the melting point of the substance. [1] - Identify the state of particles at $110\, {}^\circ\mathrm{C}$. [1]
markScheme:
- $\mbox{}\\[0pts]$
  Segment numberWhat phase(s) is/are present?What is happening at the particle level?What phase change, if any, is taking place?1SolidVibrating more/fasterNone$\checkmark$2Solid and liquidBreaking free of fixed positionsMelting$\checkmark$3LiquidMoving fasterNone$\checkmark$4Liquid and gasBreaking free of the liquid stateBoiling/Vaporising $\newline$ (Not evaporation)$\checkmark$5GasMoving quickly and randomly in all directionsNone$\checkmark$ $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}$
Evaporation refers to the particles at the surface gaining enough energy to break free of the liquid state and can take place at temperatures below the boiling temperature. The state change at segment 4 involves all particles gaining enough energy to break free of the liquid state .
- $0^\circ\mathrm{C}$ $\checkmark$
  
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}$
Segment 2 represents melting, and reading across the graph gives a  temperature of $0^\circ\mathrm{C}$
- gas $\checkmark$
  
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}$
As the temperature is greater than the boiling point, the particles are in the gaseous state.

title: Question 24
content: Biological dyes contaminated a local pond. These dyes are known to be soluble solids. A sample of the polluted pond water was collected for separation and further identification of the dyes to determine how best to remediate the area. $\hspace{2.in}$![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/760b58bf-4e46-4e5e-8e06-140c7724c06b/images/1751a225-6777-42e8-9caa-872664676f39/CH0854beaker.png) $\hspace{2.in}$ - State whether this mixture is homogeneous or heterogeneous, explaining your answer. [2] - State the technique that could be used to remove the wood chips, algae, and plant matter from the mixture. [1] - State the technique that could be used to isolate the dissolved solids (salts, dyes, etc) from the water. [1] - State the technique that could be used to separate the salts from the dyes. [1] - Explain the properties of the substances that enable their separation in question (d). [2] - Once the dyes have been separated from the remainder of the sample, paper chromatography could be used to determine how many dyes are present. State the identity of the stationary phase and an example of a mobile phase. [1] - From the following paper chromatogram, state which dye (A or B) has a greater affinity for the mobile, describing the evidence to support this answer. [2] ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/760b58bf-4e46-4e5e-8e06-140c7724c06b/images/7c6902f8-f66b-4126-8bd8-d1773d00064c/CH0854.png)
markScheme:
- heterogenous $\checkmark$
more than one component is visible/identifiable $\checkmark$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$:
Homogeneous mixtures contain more than one substance physically combined that appear as one phase (layer) throughout. These types of mixtures are indistinguishable from pure substance. A heterogeneous mixture contains more than one easily identifiable substance (several layers).
- filtration $\checkmark$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$:
If a mixture contains solids in a liquid and those solids are insoluble, then filtration is a viable method for separation.
- evaporation $\checkmark$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$:
If a mixture contains soluble solids in a solvent, the solids can be isolated by evaporating the solvent by applying heat.
- recrystallization $\checkmark$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$:
Recrystallization separates components of a solid mixture, provided that the substances have varying solvent solubility at different temperatures.
- differing solvent solubility $\checkmark$
at different temperatures $\checkmark$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$:
When recrystallizing a substance, the impure substance is dissolved in a warm liquid where the components have variable solubility in that solvent at different temperatures. This mixture is then evaporated to form a saturated solution which is subsequently placed in an ice bath. This causes the mixture's components with a lower solubility in the solvent to precipitate (form a solid), enabling it to be separated via filtration.
- stationary phase = paper; mobile phase = water $\checkmark$
The mobile phase could be any polar solvent, such as methanol or ethanol.
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$:
In paper chromatography, the stationary phase is always the paper, and the mobile phase is whichever solvent is used to separate the mixture's components.
- A $\checkmark$
Spot A has moved farther / has the larger $R_f$ $\checkmark$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$:
In paper chromatography, the components of a mixture with the greatest affinity for the solvent will move the furthest on the chromatogram. This means that the forces of attraction between the solvent and the substance are greater than between the substance and the paper.

title: Question 26
content:
A research team needs to separate a mixture containing:


- 
  
  - 
    - Vegetable oil (density $0.9 \textrm{\ g/cm}^3,$ immiscible with water)

  - 
    - Ethanol (density $0.8 \textrm{\ g/cm}^3,$ miscible with water, boiling point $78^\circ\textrm{C})$

  - 
    - Water (density $1.0 \textrm{\ g/cm}^3,$ boiling point $100^\circ\textrm{C})$



Which separation technique would be most appropriate to isolate pure water from this mixture?


- A.$\hspace{1.em}$Decanting followed by crystallization
- B.$\hspace{1.em}$Fractional distillation of the entire mixture
- C.$\hspace{1.em}$Filtration followed by evaporation
- D.$\hspace{1.em}$Simple distillation after removing the oil layer
markScheme:
D

$\textrm{\underline{Explanation:}}$
This separation requires understanding of miscibility and boiling point differences. The oil is immiscible with water and ethanol, so it can be separated first by decanting or using a separating funnel, leaving behind a homogeneous water$-$ethanol mixture. Since ethanol and water have different boiling points $(78^\circ\textrm{C}$ vs. $100^\circ\textrm{C}),$ simple distillation can separate them effectively. The ethanol will vaporize first at $78^\circ\textrm{C},$ leaving pure water behind. Fractional distillation would work but is unnecessarily complex for this large of a boiling point difference. Filtration and crystallization are inappropriate for liquid mixtures.

title: Question 27
content:
Which statement about the sequence described below is correct?
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/cb37324e-0915-4ce5-9fc8-f418bea0e2e8/images/dbfa0984-b75c-44d5-96f4-4b37b10db02c/CH1219.png)




- A.$\hspace{1em}$Sea water is a mixture, and the residue contains salt
- B.$\hspace{1em}$Sea water is a mixture, and the filtrate contains sand
- C.$\hspace{1em}$Pure NaCl is isolated through this sequence
- D.$\hspace{1em}$Distilled water can be separated through this sequence
markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Seawater is a homogeneous mixture containing more than one element or compound. Seawater is made of water with dissolved salts (not only sodium chloride), some insoluble impurities suspended, and some dissolved gases.
Physical methods, such as filtration and distillation, can be applied to separate the mixture's components.
However, only some of the components might get isolated by this sequence. Filtration allows the separation of solid, insoluble particles from the mixture. These solid particles will remain in the residue, whereas the liquid phase will go through the filter to be collected as the filtrate.
$\hspace{15em}$![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/cb37324e-0915-4ce5-9fc8-f418bea0e2e8/images/585a0e5a-01f9-45bd-ad99-cbb81612c756/CH1219filtv2.png)

$\hspace{15em}$[Created with Chemix ($\text{http}$s://chemix.org)]
If the filtrate is distilled, dissolved particles will remain in the flask, and water will be vaporized and condensed as a distillate. The liquid component can be separated with this method (water). However, in the flask, all the soluble salts will remain (this might include other salts than NaCl).
$\hspace{10em}$![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/cb37324e-0915-4ce5-9fc8-f418bea0e2e8/images/6373a973-26d0-419f-86cf-cbd094ef532f/CH1219distill.png)

$\hspace{10em}$[Created with Chemix ($\text{http}$s://chemix.org)]
The sequence is shown below:
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/cb37324e-0915-4ce5-9fc8-f418bea0e2e8/images/4d52e721-1da3-4832-89a6-dbea6d56e1a1/CH1219flow.png)


This question is categorized as medium difficulty as students are expected to recall the concept of the mixture and understand how filtration and distillation allow the separation of mixtures.

title: Question 30
content:
Paper chromatography is a technique that can be used to separate which of the following?


- A.$\hspace{1em}$A liquid and an insoluble solid
- B.$\hspace{1em}$Soluble solids
- C.$\hspace{1em}$A solid and an insoluble liquid
- D.$\hspace{1em}$Insoluble solids
markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The student must correctly understand the process of paper chromatography. Components of a mixture can be successfully separated using paper chromatography only if the components are soluble in the mobile phase (the solvent). The components of the mixture can be liquids or solids when pure.
This question is categorized as medium because the student must understand that solubility in the mobile phase is essential for a successful separation using paper chromatography. Beyond that, there are no calculations or other facts to recall.

title: Question 31
content:
A mixture of $100\textrm{\ g}$ of sand, $1.00\textrm{\ g}$ of sodium chloride, $200\textrm{\ cm}^3$ of water, and $2.00\textrm{\ g}$ of iron fillings must be separated. All the components are expected to be recovered.
Which sequence of steps would work for this purpose?


- A.$\hspace{1em}$Filtration, evaporation of the filtrate, and use of a magnet with the residue
- B.$\hspace{1em}$Filtration, evaporation of the residue, and use of a magnet with the filtrate
- C.$\hspace{1em}$Filtration, simple distillation of the filtrate and use of a magnet with the residue
- D.$\hspace{1em}$Filtration, simple distillation of the residue and use of a magnet with the filtrate
markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Filtration separates the insoluble solid mixture of sand and iron from the sodium chloride solution. The residue on the filter paper contains sand and iron, while the sodium chloride solution passes through as the filtrate.
To recover both water and sodium chloride from the filtrate, simple distillation is used. During distillation, water is collected as the distillate and sodium chloride remains in the flask. This ensures both components are obtained separately, which evaporation alone would not allow.
Finally, the residue is separated into sand and iron by using a magnet, since iron filings are magnetic. This sequence ensures that all four components are successfully recovered.
The question is of medium difficulty, as students must identify the correct order of separation techniques and understand the purpose of each step.

title: Question 32
content:
The boiling point of propan$-$2$-$ol is $82\,{}^\circ\text{C}.$
Which statement(s) below is(are) correct?


- I.$\hspace{1.em}$Evaporation of propan$-$2$-$ol can occur at $80\,{}^\circ\text{C}.$
- II.$\hspace{0.7em}$Condensation of propan$-$2$-$ol can occur at $82\,{}^\circ\text{C}.$
- III.$\hspace{0.4em}$At $100\,{}^\circ\text{C}$, propan$-$2$-$ol molecules are close together and randomly arranged.



- A.$\hspace{1em}$I only
- B.$\hspace{1em}$II only
- C.$\hspace{1em}$I and II only
- D.$\hspace{1em}$III only
markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Evaporation is the change from liquid to gas at the surface of a liquid and can occur at any temperature below the boiling point. Therefore, propan$-$2$-$ol can evaporate at $80,{}^\circ\text{C}$, making Statement I correct.
The boiling point is also the condensation point, since it is the temperature at which liquid and gas are in equilibrium. Propan$-$2$-$ol can both boil and condense at $82,{}^\circ\text{C}$, so Statement II is correct.
At $100,{}^\circ\text{C}$, propan$-$2$-$ol is above its boiling point and exists as a gas. In the gaseous state, particles are far apart and move randomly, not close together. This means Statement III is incorrect.
This is a challenging question, as it requires students to distinguish between evaporation and boiling, apply the idea that boiling and condensation occur at the same temperature, and link these concepts to the particle model of matter.

title: Question 33
content:
A solution of propan$-$1$-$ol and propan$-$2$-$ol must be separated. The full structural formulas of these are given below.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/00dedc88-7e57-4767-96b3-881206963b72/images/a60e3a4b-67bc-4abd-ae31-a49cda8a6d52/CH1095.png)


Which statement(s) is(are) correct?


- I.$\hspace{1.em}$Distillation allows the separation of the components of this mixture.
- II.$\hspace{0.7em}$A condenser, thermometer, and evaporating basin are needed for distillation.
- III.$\hspace{0.4em}$The distillate would be propan$-$2$-$ol.



- A.$\hspace{1em}$I and II only
- B.$\hspace{1em}$I and III only
- C.$\hspace{1em}$III only
- D.$\hspace{1em}$II only
markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Distillation is used to separate mixtures of miscible liquids with different boiling points, so Statement I is correct. The process involves heating the mixture until the more volatile liquid (the one with the lower boiling point) vaporizes, then condensing and collecting this vapor as the distillate. The less volatile component remains in the distillation flask.
Here is the typical setup:
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/00dedc88-7e57-4767-96b3-881206963b72/images/8bca4d25-da81-4aca-91e2-e91a58ca3eea/unnamed%20(1).png)


$\footnotesize{\textrm{[Â© Revision Village 2023. Created with Chemix (https://chemix.org)]}}$
Statement II is incorrect because an evaporating basin is not used in distillation; the essential apparatus includes a distillation flask, a condenser, and a thermometer.
Statement III is correct because propan$-$2$-$ol has more branching than propan$-$1$-$ol, leading to weaker intermolecular forces and therefore a lower boiling point. This means propan$-$2$-$ol vaporizes and is collected first as the distillate.
This question is of moderate difficulty since it requires both knowledge of distillation as a separation technique and an understanding of how molecular structure affects boiling points.

title: Question 35
content:
A gas is placed in a sealed rigid container and heated. What happens to the gas particles according to the kinetic molecular theory?


- A. $\hspace{1em}$They move faster and collide more frequently with each other, but the pressure remains constant.
- B. $\hspace{1em}$They gain kinetic energy and move faster, increasing collisions with the container walls, which increases pressure.
- C. $\hspace{1em}$They expand within the container, increasing the density of the gas.
- D. $\hspace{1em}$They gain kinetic energy, but temperature remains constant as intermolecular forces are overcome.
markScheme:
B

$\textrm{\underline{Explanation:}}$
According to the kinetic molecular theory, when a gas is heated, the particles gain kinetic energy and move faster. Since the gas is in a sealed rigid container, the volume remains constant, meaning the only way for the gas to respond to heating is by increasing pressure. This happens because faster$\text{--}$moving particles collide more frequently and with greater force against the container walls, as described by Gay$\text{--}$Lussac's Law $(P\propto T$ at constant volume).

title: Question 38
content:
Which statement correctly describes the behavior of particles during the phase change from liquid to gas at the boiling point?


- A. $\hspace{1em}$Particles remain in the liquid phase until the temperature exceeds the boiling point.
- B. $\hspace{1em}$Particles absorb energy to overcome intermolecular forces, causing a continuous rise in temperature.
- C. $\hspace{1em}$Particles absorb energy to overcome intermolecular forces, but the temperature remains constant.
- D. $\hspace{1em}$Particles experience no change in energy while transitioning from liquid to gas.
markScheme:
C

$\textrm{\underline{Explanation:}}$
During boiling, all heat energy supplied to the system is used to break intermolecular forces, allowing the substance to transition from liquid to gas. The kinetic energy of the particles does not increase, meaning the temperature remains constant until the phase change is complete. This is evident in a heating curve, where the plateau at the boiling point indicates that energy is being used for vaporization rather than raising temperature.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/036ac452-cb2a-430e-b1ac-408d86f09a5b/images/35fd9e9e-afe4-420e-9a46-4319fab8a71a/CH2082.png)

title: Question 39
content:
A sample of ethanol is placed in an open container. Over time, the volume of the liquid decreased, even though the temperature remained constant at 25$^\circ\text{C}.$
Select the statement that best describes this phenomenon.


- A. $\hspace{1em}$Ethanol molecules at the surface vaporized at a temperature below boiling point.
- B. $\hspace{1em}$Ethanol intermolecular forces are weaker at the surface, leading to vaporization.
- C. $\hspace{1em}$Ethanol molecules reached the boiling point and vaporized.
- D. $\hspace{1em}$Ethanol molecules underwent a decrease in pressure, leading to vaporization.
markScheme:
A

$\textrm{\underline{Explanation:}}$
Evaporation occurs when molecules at the surface gain enough kinetic energy to overcome intermolecular forces and escape into the gas phase, even without reaching the boiling point. Unlike boiling, which requires the entire liquid to reach a specific temperature, evaporation happens gradually at any temperature.

title: Question 40
content:
During a calorimetry experiment, a student recorded the initial and final temperature of a sample in the table below:
Temperature /$^\circ$C$\\$ $\mathbf\pm 0.5^\circ$C$\ \ \ \ \ $Initial$\ \ \ \ \ $18.0Final72.0
What is the temperature change in Kelvin, including its uncertainty?


- A. $\hspace{1em}327.0\pm 1.0\text{ K}$
- B. $\hspace{1em}327.0\pm 0.5\text{ K}$
- C. $\hspace{1em}54.0\pm 1.0\text{ K}$
- D. $\hspace{1em}54.0\pm 0.5\text{ K}$
markScheme:
C

$\textrm{\underline{Explanation:}}$
The correct answer is $54.0\pm 1.0\text{ K}$ because the temperature change in Kelvin is equal to the temperature change in Celsius, meaning we simply subtract:
$72.0^\circ\text{C} - 18.0^\circ\text{C} = 54.0^\circ\text{C}$
The Kelvin scale is shifted by $273.15^\circ\text{C},$ but the degrees are the same size as Celsius degrees. Alternatively, both temperature can be converted to Kelvin before the subtraction
$345.15\text{ K} - 291.15\text{ K} = 54.0\text{ K}$
For the uncertainty, since we are subtracting two measured values, we must add their absolute uncertainties:
$(\pm 0.5\text{ K}) + (\pm 0.5\text{K}) = \pm 1.0\text{ K}$
This gives a final result of $54.0\pm 1.0\text{ K}.$

title: Question 42
content:
A mixture is investigated through paper chromatography, comparing it with standards X, Y, and Z. The development of the chromatograph allows the interpretation of the results shown below.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/ce658891-f7b1-4bd2-8eca-c19f7241f8b4/images/08815fef-1bd2-442a-9d73-ea5db26ea175/CH1096.png)


Which statement(s) is(are) correct?


- I.$\hspace{1.em}$X and Y are present in the mixture.
- II.$\hspace{0.7em}$Z is not present in the mixture
- III.$\hspace{0.4em}$The mixture must contain four components.



- A.$\hspace{1em}$I only
- B.$\hspace{1em}$I and II only
- C.$\hspace{1em}$I, II, and III
- D.$\hspace{1em}$II and III only
markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
In paper chromatography, a solvent rises through the paper by capillary action and carries the components of a mixture with it. Different substances travel at different rates depending on their interactions with the paper and the solvent, producing a pattern of separated spots. The position of each spot can be expressed using the retention factor:
$R_f = \dfrac{\text{distance moved by the spot}}{\text{distance moved by the solvent front}}$
Retention factors range between 0 and 1 and provide a way to compare spots.
In the chromatogram, the mixture has separated into four distinct spots. The same $R_f$ value is seen in both the mixture and standard X, showing that X is present. Similarly, both spots of standard Y are also present in the mixture, so Y is included as well. Standard Z, however, has two spots not both present in the mixture, so Z is not included. Although four spots are visible in the mixture, this only proves that it contains at least four components$\text{---}$some spots may still contain more than one substance. Therefore, Statements I and II are correct, and Statement III is not.
This question is categorized as medium difficulty as students must recall how chromatography works and interpret results for a specific case.

title: Question 1
content:
Which of the following statements is false?


- I.$\hspace{1em}$Electrons have greater mass than protons and neutronsII.$\hspace{1em}$Protons and neutrons are in the nucleusIII.$\hspace{1em}$Protons and electrons are charged subatomic particlesIV.$\hspace{1em}$Electrons are located outside the nucleus



- A.$\hspace{1em}$I and III only
- B.$\hspace{1em}$II and IV only
- C.$\hspace{1em}$II only
- D.$\hspace{1em}$I only
markScheme:
D
$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Electrons have negligible mass.

title: Question 2
content:
The nuclear symbol for an isotope of iodine is $\ce{^{125}_{53}I}$. Which of the following is correct about the isotope?

Atomic NumberMass NumberNumber of protonsNumber of neutronsNumber of electrons$\hspace{1em}$ A.$\hspace{1em}$53125537253$\hspace{1em}$ B.$\hspace{1em}$53125725353$\hspace{1em}$ C.$\hspace{1em}$12553537272$\hspace{1em}$ D.$\hspace{1em}$12553535372
markScheme:
A
$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/42307e35-8608-4db2-8772-65b60ebe1e65/images/67b4491b-77e7-4bdb-ab9a-3bfc9f01f1dd/2.1-48.png)


The mass number is the sum of the number of protons and neutrons. For a neutral atom, the number of electrons is equal to the number of protons.

title: Question 7
content:
How many electrons are there in $\ce{^{35}_{17}Cl^-}$?


- A.$\hspace{1em}$ 17
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ 18
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ 35
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ 36
markScheme:
B
$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The atomic number is 17, hence there are 17 protons and 17 electrons in the atom (since atom is neutral). The ion with a charge of (1-) means that the atom has gained 1 electron and therefore, contains 18 electrons.

title: Question 8
content:
The following table shows the number of subatomic particles present in five species.
SpeciesNumber of protonsNumber of neutronsNumber of electronsR888S8810T9108U101010V101210
Which two species are isotopes of the same element?


- A.$\hspace{1em}$R and S
- B.$\hspace{1em}$S and T
- C.$\hspace{1em}$T and U
- D.$\hspace{1em}$U and V
markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Isotopes have the same number of protons but different numbers of neutrons.
Species R and S have the same number of protons but also the same number of neutrons so cannot be isotopes. S is an anion of element R.
Species T is the only species in the table with 9 protons so cannot have an isotope with another species in the table because it is a different element.
This leaves species U and V which both have the same number of protons but a different number of neutrons so they are isotopes.

title: Question 14
content:
Which combination is correct for $\ce{^{41}_{19}K{^+}}?$
$\mbox{}\\[-15pts]$
$\hspace{1.em}$Number of protonsNumber of neutronsNumber of electronsA.192218B.192220C.224120D.221918
markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The nuclear symbol notation allows to deduce the number of protons, neutrons and electrons.
$\LARGE{\ce{_Z^A X^q}}$X$\textrm{Chemical symbol}$ $\hspace{0.1em}$ $\mathbf{A}$Mass number protons + neutrons$\mathbf{Z}$Atomic number protons$\mathbf{q}$Chargeprotons $-$ electrons
In this symbol:


- $Z = 19$, the number of protons.
- $A=41$, there are $41 - 19 = 22$ neutrons.
- $q = +1$, there are $19-1=18$ electrons.

This question is categorized as easy as students must be able to calculate the number of protons, neutrons, and electrons by interpreting the nuclear symbol notation.

title: Question 17
content:
Which isotope has the greatest number of neutrons?


- A. $\hspace{1em}\ce{^14_6C}$
- B. $\hspace{1em}\ce{^16_8O}$
- C. $\hspace{1em}\ce{^18_9F}$
- D. $\hspace{1em}\ce{^20_10Ne}$
markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation:}}$
The number of neutrons in an atom can be found using the following formula:
Mass number = # protons + # neutrons
In the isotopes written in this question, the top number is the mass number and the lower number is the atomic number which equals the number of protons. Therefore, the number of neutrons for each is:
IsotopeMass NumberAtomic NumberProtonsNeutrons$\ce{^14_6C}$1466$14-6=8$ $\ce{^16_8O}$1688$16-8=8$ $\ce{^18_9F}$1899$18-9=9$ $\ce{^20_10Ne}$201010$\mathbf{20-10=10}$

title: Question 18
content:
Which of the following statements about atomic structure is incorrect?


- A. $\hspace{1em}$The atomic nucleus contains over $99.9\%$ of an atom's mass.
- B. $\hspace{1em}$The number of neutrons in an atom typically increases as the atomic number increases.
- C. $\hspace{1em}$The mass of an electron is approximately $1/1836$ of a proton's mass.
- D. $\hspace{1em}$Electrons orbit the nucleus in fixed orbits, similar to planets orbiting the Sun.
markScheme:
D

$\textrm{\underline{Explanation:}}$
While early models of the atom, such as Bohr's atomic model, proposed that electrons move in fixed circular orbits around the nucleus, modern quantum mechanics has replaced this idea. Instead of fixed paths, electrons exist in probability clouds called orbitals, where their exact location cannot be determined. These orbitals are described by quantum mechanics, where electrons behave more like waves than particles in fixed orbits. Therefore, the idea of electrons orbiting the nucleus like planets is an outdated model that does not accurately describe atomic structure.

title: Question 20
content: [Maximum marks: 6] Lead white is a pigment historically used by artists to achieve a warm white. It is no longer commonly used today due to its toxicity. - A sample from one painting was analyzed, and it was found that the lead pigment contained two isotopes of lead with mass numbers 206 and 208, in a ratio of $3:2.$ - Define the term isotope. [1] - Calculate the relative atomic mass of lead in the sample. Show your working [2] - In another pigment sample, the relative atomic mass of lead was determined to be 207.6. - Suggest why the relative atomic masses differ between the samples. [1] - Predict and explain whether the lead present in both samples would have the same physical and chemical properties. [2]
markScheme:
- 
  - two atoms with the same number of protons and  different number of neutrons$\checkmark$
    $\textrm{\underline{Further Explanation:}}$
    Isotopes are atoms of the same element (so they have the same number of protons), but they have different numbers of neutrons, which means they have different mass numbers. This affects the atomic mass but not the chemical behavior.
  - $\dfrac{(206.0)(3) + (208.0)(2)}{5}$ OR $\dfrac{(206.0)(60) + (208.0)(40)}{100}\ \checkmark$
    $206.8\ \checkmark$
    $\textrm{\underline{Further Explanation:}}$
    The relative atomic mass is the weighted average of the mass of each isotope. With a $3:2$ ratio, the percent abundance is $60:40.$
    $A_r = \sum \dfrac{\text{mass of isotope}\times \text{percent abundance}}{100}$ $A_r = \dfrac{(206.0)(60) + (208.0)(40)}{100} = 206.8$

- 
  - any of the following:
    
    - different sources/geological origins of the lead $\checkmark$
    - different manufacturing/refining processes used to prepare pigments$\checkmark$
    - small sample size so different distribution of isotopes $\checkmark$

    $\textrm{\underline{Further Explanation:}}$
    Different lead samples can come from different mines or regions, and the natural abundance of isotopes varies slightly depending on the geological source. That is why one sample could have more $^{206}\ce{Pb},$ while another has more $^{208}\ce{Pb}.$
  - chemical properties same: same number of electrons/same electron configuration $\checkmark$
    physical properties may differ: different mass/boiling point/density/rate of diffusion $\checkmark$
    $\textrm{\underline{Further Explanation:}}$
    The chemical properties would be the same because both isotopes of lead have the same number of electrons. Chemical reactions depend on the electron arrangement, not the number of neutrons. However, the physical properties (like mass, density, diffusion rate, boiling/melting points) would be different due to the difference in mass.

title: Question 21
content:
What is the relative atomic mass of an element with the following isotopic mass data?
$\newline \ $
Isotope mass% abundance15022.0015151.0015227.00


- A.$\hspace{1em}$151.00
- B.$\hspace{1em}$154.50
- C.$\hspace{1em}$1.51
- D.$\hspace{1em}$151.05
markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation:}}$
To answer this question, the student must use the following formula to find the relative atomic mass, $A_r$:
$A_r = \dfrac{m_1\times a_1 + m_2\times a_2 + \ldots}{100}$
where $m_i$ is the mass of an isotope in amu and $a_i$ is the abundance of that isotope expressed in percent.
For this question,
$A_r = \dfrac{(150 \times 22.00) + (151 \times 51.00) + (152 \times 27.00)}{100} = 151.05$
This question is categorized as medium difficulty because the student must know how to calculate a weighted average as opposed to a regular average. For example, if the student were to simply average 150, 151 and 152, then they would arrive at the answer 151.00 amu, while the true answer of 151.05 amu accounts for the weighted average of the isotopes.

title: Question 23
content:
What is the relative atomic mass, $A_r$, of an unknown element found in a meteorite with the isotopic abundances shown below?
Isotope% Abundance$^{39}\ce{X}$80.0$^{40}\ce{X}$1.0$^{41}\ce{X}$19.0


- A.$\hspace{1em}$39.00
- B.$\hspace{1em}$40.00
- C.$\hspace{1em}$39.39
- D.$\hspace{1em}$40.50
markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Based on calculations, the relative atomic mass of $\ce{X}$ is:
$A_r = \dfrac{\left(39\times 80.0\right)+\left(40\times 1.00\right)+(41\times 19.00\ )}{100} = 39.39$
Students are not required to work out the calculation. the $A_r$ cab be estimated to be close to 39 due to the high percent abundance of that isotope, but slightly higher due to the existence of the more massive isotopes.

title: Question 25
content: Element Y has 4 stable isotopes. The table below shows the relative abundance and atomic masses of these isotopes. IsotopePercent abundanceAtomic mass11.40%203.97224.10%205.97322.10%206.98452.40%207.98 $\mbox{}\\[-25pts]$ - Calculate the relative atomic mass of the element. [2] - Identify the element. [1] - The atom of the element can form an ion with a charge of 4+. Determine the number of electrons in the ion. [1] - Determine the nuclear symbol of another corresponding ion of element Y given the numbers of subatomic particles: electrons = 80; neutrons = 122. [1]
markScheme:
- $A_r = (203.97) (0.014) + (205.97) (0.241)+ (206.98) (0.221) + (207.98)(0.524) \: \checkmark$
$A_r = 207.2 \: \checkmark$ 
$\textit{Award 2 marks for complete correct answer}$.
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}$
Relative atomic mass is the sum of each atomic mass of each isotope multiplied by its percentage abundance.
- Pb \ lead $\checkmark$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}$
The element with a relative atomic mass equal to 207.2 is lead.
- 78 $\checkmark$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}$
The element is lead (Pb). Lead has an atomic number of 82. This means that a neutral atom of lead has 82 protons and 82 electrons. Its atom loses 4 electrons $(82-4)$ and becomes a cation with a charge of $4+$, $\ce{Pb^{4+}}.$
- Nuclear symbol: $\ce{^{204}_{82}Pb^{2+}}$ $\checkmark$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}$
There are 80 electrons in the corresponding ion. This means that the atom has lost 2 electrons and has a become an ion of charge 2+.
  Mass number = protons + neutrons = $82 + 122 = 204$

title: Question 26
content:
Given below is the mass spectrum of the stable isotopes of rubidium (Rb). What is the relative atomic mass of rubidium?
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/6e3db916-1d81-4664-9ab6-a5028574d644/images/627f7e43-e21d-4f9a-830f-cb78841ea511/CH0053.png)




- A.$\hspace{1em}$ 85.5
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ 86.7
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ 85.9
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ 87.4
markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The approximate height of each peak is the relative abundance of each isotope.
$\hspace{4em}$Rb$\text{--}$85 $\sim$ 75 %
$\hspace{4em}$Rb$\text{--}$87 $\sim$ 25 %
Rb$\text{--}$85 is the most abundant isotope within a large difference, therefore,  the relative atomic mass should be closer to 85 than 87. 85.5 is the most reasonable answer.
Mathematically, we can calculate the weighted average of the mass:
$\begin{aligned} m &= \dfrac{75}{100}\times 85 + \dfrac{25}{100}\times 87\\
\\
 &= \dfrac{75}{100}\times 85 + \dfrac{25}{100}\times (85+2)\\
 \\
&= \dfrac{75}{100}\times 85 + \dfrac{25}{100}\times 85 + \dfrac{25}{100}\times 2\\
\\
&   = 85 +  \dfrac{25}{100}\times 2 = 85.5\\
\end{aligned}$

title: Question 29
content:
Which property is most likely to differ between two isotopes of the same element?


- A. $\hspace{1em}$The strength of chemical bonds they form in compounds.
- B. $\hspace{1em}$Their ability to conduct electricity in the solid state.
- C. $\hspace{1em}$Their reactivity with acids and bases.
- D. $\hspace{1em}$Their diffusion rate in gases.
markScheme:
D

$\textrm{\underline{Explanation:}}$
Isotopes have the same number of protons and electrons, meaning their chemical properties remain identical. This includes their ability to form chemical bonds and react with acids or bases. However, isotopes have different numbers of neutrons, leading to variations in their atomic mass which affects physical properties. In gases, the diffusion rate is inversely proportional to the square root of the atomic mass (as described by Graham's Law). Lighter isotopes diffuse faster than heavier isotopes, making diffusion rate the key property that differs between isotopes.
While some physical properties vary between isotopes, such as density and melting point, properties like electrical conductivity remain unchanged. Conductivity depends on the movement of free electrons, which is not influenced by the nuclear mass.

title: Question 1
content:
What is the maximum number of electrons in the $4p$ subshell?


- A.$\hspace{1em}$ 6
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ 10
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ 2
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ 8
markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
For $p$, $l$ is equal to 1. The number of electrons in a given subshell can be calculated using the formula:
$2(2\,l + 1) = 2((2)(1) + 1) = 6$ electrons
The $p$ subshell holds 3 orbitals. Each orbital can fit 2 electrons. Therefore, $p$ subshell holds 6 electrons.

title: Question 5
content:
Which of the following is the correct electron configuration of a typical sodium ion?


- A.$\hspace{1em}$ $\ce{[Ne]}\, 3s^1$
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ $\ce{[Ne]}\, 3s^2$
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ $\ce{[Ne]}$
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ $\ce{[Ne]}\, 2s^1$
markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The atomic number of sodium is 11. Its electron configuration follows the Aufbau principle, filling the electron sublevels from lowest to highest energy.
$\ce{Na}$: $1s^2 2s^2 2p^6 3s^1$
This can be rewritten in noble gas or shorthand notation by observing that the noble gas neon has the same core electron filling $(\ce{Ne}:\, 1s^2 2s^2 2p^6)$.  The electron configuration of neutral sodium can be rewritten as
$\ce{Na}$:$ \ [\ce{Ne}]\,3s^1$
The atom loses one electron to become a stable ion with a charge of 1+ (10 electrons). The removed electron is from the valence shell (the $3s$ electron).  The electron configuration of sodium ion is
$\ce{Na^+}$:$ \ [\ce{Ne}]$
Alternatively, notice that sodium ion is isoelectronic with neon so mush share its electron configuration.

title: Question 12
content:
What will happen to the frequency of moving light particles if the wavelength is doubled, assuming the velocity is constant?


- A.$\hspace{1em}$ The frequency will be doubled
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ The frequency will decrease by half
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ The frequency will not be affected
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ The frequency will increase by four
markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
There is an inverse relationship between frequency and wavelength. If the wavelength is doubled, the frequency will decrease by half. Therefore, Choices A, C, and D are all incorrect.

title: Question 13
content:
Which of the following statement(s) is (are) true?


- I.The emission spectra are produced from a release of energy of excited electronsII.No two electrons in one atom have the same set of quantum numbersIII.The electrons in an orbital must have an opposite spin



- A.$\hspace{1em}$ I only
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ II and III only
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ I and II only
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ I, II, and III
markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Statement I is true because emission spectra are produced when photons are released from excited electrons returning to lower energy levels.
Statement II is true because this is Pauli's Exclusion principle.
Statement III is also true because it is included in Pauli's Exclusion principle.

title: Question 15
content:
Which of the following correctly compares the $2s$ and $3s$ atomic orbitals?


- Average distance from the nucleusOrbital energyA.$\hspace{1em}$ $2s > 3s$ $2s < 3s$B.$2s > 3s$ $2s > 3s$C.$2s < 3s$ $2s < 3s$D.$2s < 3s$ $2s > 3s$
markScheme:
C

$\textrm{\underline{Explanation:}}$
The $3s$ orbital is larger than the $2s$ orbital so an electron in a $3s$ orbital is, on average, farther from the nucleus than one in a $2s$ orbital. Additionally, the $3s$ orbital is higher in energy because electrons in higher energy levels experience weaker electrostatic attraction to the nucleus, due to increased shielding by inner electrons and greater average distance. Therefore, both the average distance and the energy of the $3s$ orbital are greater than those of the $2s$ orbital.

title: Question 16
content:
What is the ground state electron configuration of an atom of an element in Group 16 of the periodic table?


- A. $\hspace{1em}1s^2\ 2s^2\ 2p^2$
- B. $\hspace{1em}1s^2\ 2s^2\ 2p^4$
- C. $\hspace{1em}1s^2\ 2s^2\ 2p^6\ 3s^2\ 3p^6\ 4s^2\ 3d^6$
- D. $\hspace{1em}1s^2\ 2s^2\ 2p^6\ 3s^2\ 3p^6\ 4s^2\ 3d^{10}\ 4p^6$
markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
To identify the electron configuration of an element in Group 16 of the periodic table, we need to find the configuration that ends with $ns^2\ np^4$
Let's examine each given configuration:
ConfigurationValence ElectronsGroupElement$2s^2\ 2p^2$414C$2s^2\ 2p^4$616O$4s^2\ 3d^6$88Fe$4s^2\ 4p^6$818Kr

title: Question 18
content: Cobalt-60 is a radioactive isotope of the element cobalt that is used to treat thyroid cancer. - - State the full electron configuration of cobalt and chromium. [2] - Explain what is special about the electron configuration of chromium. [1] - State the atomic symbol notation for the cobalt-60 isotope. [1] One atom of cobalt-60 undergoes beta decay, releasing an electron and energy with a frequency of $7.65\times 10^{19}$ Hz to form nickel-60. - - Using section 1 of the data booklet, calculate the wavelength of energy released from beta decay. [1] - Using section 3 (Section 5- 2025 Syllabus) of the data booklet and your answer to (b) (i), deduce the type of electromagnetic radiation emitted. [1] - - Define orbital. [1] - Sketch the shapes of an s-orbital and a p-orbital. [2]
markScheme:
- 
  - Co: $1s^2\,2s^2\,2p^6\,3s^2\,3p^6\,4s^2\,3d^7$. $\checkmark$
    Cr: $1s^2\,2s^2\,2p^6\,3s^2\,3p^6\,4s^1\,3d^5$ $\checkmark$
    $\underline{\textrm{Further explanation:}}$
    We first need the number of electrons in the element which can be found from its atomic number. Orbitals are filled from lowest energy to highest energy - $1s,\,2s,\,2p,\,3s,\,3p,\,4s,\,3d$. Remembering that there are $1s$ orbital, $3p$ orbitals and $5d$ orbitals, with each orbital housing at most two electrons, we can write the electron configuration of cobalt. Chromium is an exception to filling the $4s$ orbital before the $3d$ orbitals and instead is $4s^13d^5$ instead of $4s^2\,3d^4$.
  - Based on the elements preceding chromium, we would expect chromium to have an electron configuration of $1s^2\,2s^2\,2p^6\,3s^2\,3p^6\,4s^2\,3d^4$ but instead it is $1s^2\,2s^22p^6\,3s^2\,3p^6\,4s^1\,3d^5$ due to the relative energies of the $4s$ and $3d$ orbitals. $\checkmark$
    $\underline{\textrm{Further explanation:}}$
    Hund's rule states that degenerate orbitals should be first singly filled before pairing electrons up but due to the relative energies of the $4s$ and $3d$ orbitals, the $4s^1\,3d^5$ configuration of chromium is possible and more stable than the $4s^2\,3d^4$ so it is favoured.
  - $\ce{^{60}_{27}Co}$ $\checkmark$
    $\underline{\textrm{Further explanation:}}$
    The atomic number is the bottom number which can be found using the periodic table and the mass number which is given in the question is the top number. Co is the atomic symbol for cobalt.

- 
  - $c = f\lambda \quad \Longrightarrow \quad \lambda = \dfrac{c}{f} = \dfrac{3\times 10^8}{7.65\times 10^{19}} = \answer{3.92\times 10^{-12}\text{m}}\,\checkmark$
    $\underline{\textrm{Further explanation:}}$
    Using the data booklet, we can find the relevant equation  $c = f\lambda$. Next, we need to rearrange the equation to make wavelength the subject. Then, we substitute the frequency from the question and the speed of light constant from the data booklet to calculate the wavelength in meters.
  - Gamma rays. $\checkmark$
    $\underline{\textrm{Further explanation:}}$
    Using the data booklet, we can see that $10^{-12}$ m lies in the region of gamma rays.

- 
  - Orbitals represent the location where there is a high probability of finding an electron. $\checkmark$
  - ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/23a03711-709f-4957-978a-be474aff7fca/images/7a65b43c-68c9-4a9d-8ada-3f0c64026c49/2-685cii.png)


    $\underline{\textrm{Further explanation:}}$
    Each orbital has a specific shape which represents the region where there is a high probability of finding an electron $-$ $s$-orbitals are spherical and p-orbitals are dumbbell shaped.

title: Question 20
content:
In an atom with many electrons, which set of orbitals is arranged in order of lowest electron energy to highest electron energy?


- A.$\hspace{1em}2p, 3d, 4s, 4p$
- B.$\hspace{1em}4s, 2p, 4p, 3d$
- C.$\hspace{1em}2p, 4s, 3d, 4p$
- D.$\hspace{1em}2p, 4s, 4p, 3d$
markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation:}}$
Electrons fill sublevels according to the Aufbau Principle shown below:
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/2c0a4e08-133c-402d-8e75-db2d84192445/images/cbfc092e-d8aa-4e64-9b84-a94c1674e5b6/CH0775.png)


Following this order, $2p < 4s < 3d < 4p$

title: Question 22
markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
$\ce{Cu}$ and $\ce{Cu+}$ have the following electron configurations:
$\ce{Cu}:\quad 1s^2\,2s^2\,2p^6\,3s^2\,3p^6\,4s^1\,3d^{10}$
$\ce{Cu+}:\quad 1s^2\,2s^2\,2p^6\,3s^2\,3p^6\,3d^{10}$
The valence electron lost in the $\ce{Cu+}$ ion is the electron in the $4s$ sublevel.

title: Question 23
content:
Which of the following elements has more electrons in the third energy level than in the second?


- A. $\hspace{1em}$Potassium
- B. $\hspace{1em}$Calcium
- C. $\hspace{1em}$Scandium
- D. $\hspace{1em}$Sulfur
markScheme:
C

$\textbf{\underline{Explanation:}}$
Consider the electron configuration of each atom.  Using the Aufbau principle, and placing the electrons in order of increasing energy, we find:
ElementElectron Configuration$\quad \mathbf{n=2} \quad$ $\quad \mathbf{n=3} \quad$S$1s^2\ 2s^2\ 2p^6\ 3s^2\ 3p^4$ $\ce{8 eâ»}$ $\ce{6 eâ»}$K$1s^2\ 2s^2\ 2p^6\ 3s^2\ 3p^6\ 4s^1$ $\ce{8 eâ»}$ $\ce{8 eâ»}$Ca$1s^2\ 2s^2\ 2p^6\ 3s^2\ 3p^6\ 4s^2$ $\ce{8 eâ»}$ $\ce{8 eâ»}$Sc$1s^2\ 2s^2\ 2p^6\ 3s^2\ 3p^6\ 4s^2\ 3d^1$ $\ce{8 eâ»}$ $\ce{9 eâ»}$
Only scandium has more electrons in the $n=3$ level, due to placing an electron in the $3d\text{-}$sublevel.

title: Question 24
content:
Which of the following pairs of terms describe the shape of an $s-$orbital and the relative energy of a $d-$orbital?


- $\enskip\textbf{Shape of \textit{s--}orbital}\enskip$ $\enskip \textbf{Relative energy of \textit{d--}orbital}\enskip$ $\hspace{1em}$A.$\hspace{1em}$SphericalLow$\hspace{1em}$B.$\hspace{1em}$Dumbbell$-$shapeHigh$\hspace{1em}$C.$\hspace{1em}$SphericalHigh$\hspace{1em}$D.$\hspace{1em}$Dumbbell$-$shapeLow
markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The $s-$orbital has a spherical shape. In terms of energy, $s$ has the lowest, followed by $p$ and $d-$orbitals. Thus, Choices A, B, and D are all incorrect.

title: Question 25
content: Manganese presents a variety of oxidation states. - Deduce the number of electrons in $\ce{Mn^2+}.$ [1] - Annotate the diagram below showing $4s$ and $3d$ orbitals for $\ce{Mn^2+}$ using an arrow to represent the electron. [1] ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/edb5877a-7379-4264-85a7-bb23f06e6b0a/images/5187fdb0-7f67-4f43-8bea-03f13ed342a2/unnamed%20(20).png) - Deduce the condensed electron configuration of $\ce{Mn^7+}.$ [1]
markScheme:
- 23 $\checkmark$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$:
  Mn has 25 electrons. It loses 2 electrons, so $\ce{Mn^{2+}}$ has 23 electrons.
- $\mbox{}\\[-30pts]$
  $\ \ \ \  \ $![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/edb5877a-7379-4264-85a7-bb23f06e6b0a/images/beef272b-28c3-4a37-8177-6591746d64ea/unnamed%20(21).png)

$\checkmark$
  Do not penalize the omission of the $4s$ orbital.
- $\ce{[Ar]}$ OR $\ce{[Ne]}3s^2\,3p^6\,\checkmark$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$:
  Mn has 25 electrons. It loses 7 electrons, so $\ce{Mn^7+}$ has 18 electrons. If we apply the Aufbau principle, Hund's rule, and the Pauli exclusion principle, its electronic configuration turns out to be $1s^2\,2s^2\,2p^6\,3s^2\,3p^6.$

title: Question 31
content: $\ce{Cu}$ is a transition metal commonly used in wires. - Determine the complete electron configuration of $\ce{Cu}$. [1] - State the condensed electron configuration of $\ce{Cu+}.$ [1] - Determine whether the electron configuration of $\ce{Cu}$ follows the usual rules of electron configuration. [1]
markScheme:
- Longhand/complete electron configuration of $\ce{Cu}$
  $\ce{1s^2 2s^2 2p^6 3s^2 3p^6 3d^{10} 4s^1}\,\checkmark$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}$
  $\ce{Cu}$ is one of the exceptions where a $3d$ orbital would fill before $4s$ and this is due to the fact that a full $3d$ orbital is more stable.
- Condensed electron configuration
  $\ce{[Ar]\,3d^{10}}\,\checkmark$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}$
  1 electron lost from $4s$ orbital (highest energy level).
- There is an anomaly with the electron configuration of $\ce{Cu}$ simply because there is slightly greater stability associated with the fully filled ($3d^{10}$) subshell than the incomplete one. Hence, the $3d^{10}$ is filled first before pairing the $4s$ subshell. $\checkmark$

title: Question 32
content:
How many fully occupied $p$ orbitals are present in a ground$\text{--}$state arsenic (As) atom?


- A. $\hspace{1em}$2
- B. $\hspace{1em}$3
- C. $\hspace{1em}$6
- D. $\hspace{1em}$7
markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
From its placement in Period 4 of the periodic table, arsenic will have two completely filled $p$ subshells, or 6 filled $p$ orbitals. The condensed electron configuration of arsenic is  $[\text{Ar}]\ 4s^2\ 3d^{10}\ 4p^3.$ Hund's rule reminds us that the three valence $p$ electrons in arsenic will singly$\text{--}$occupy the three $4p$ orbitals. There will be 6 fully occupied $p$ orbitals.

title: Question 35
content:
An element has the electron configuration $1s^2\,2s^2\,2p^6\,3s^2\,3p^6\,4s^2\,3d^7$. Which of the below gives this element the correct number of energy levels, block, and group?


- Energy levelsBlockGroupA.$\hspace{1em}$3$s$2B.$\hspace{1em}$3$d$7C.$\hspace{1em}$4$s$7D.$\hspace{1em}$4$d$9
markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation:}}$
This highest principal energy level is 4 ($4s^2$).
The subshell being filled is $3d$, making it a $d-$block element. Its position in the $d-$block and the total number of valence electrons, being 9 ($4s^2 + 3d^7$), places this element in group 9.

title: Question 36
content:
Which of the following does NOT have two valence electrons?


- A. $\hspace{1em}$Al$^+$
- B. $\hspace{1em}$Zn
- C. $\hspace{1em}$Ca
- D. $\hspace{1em}$Sc$^{3+}$
markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation:}}$
Electron configuration of Al$^+$: [Ne] $3s^2$
Electron configuration of Zn: [Ar] $4s^2$ $3d^{10}$
Electron configuration of Ca: [Ar] $4s^2$
Electron configuration of Sc: [Ar] $4s^2$ $3d^1$.
Sc will lose 2 electrons in the 4s sublevel and 1 from the 3d sublevel, leaving a complete 3rd energy level with 8 valence electrons in Sc$^{3+}$ ($1s^2\,2s^2\,2p^6\,3s^2\,3p^6$).

title: Question 39
content:
Which electrons are lost in the formation of a copper (II)  ion from a copper atom?


- A. $\hspace{1em}$One $3s$ electron and one $3d$ electron
- B. $\hspace{1em}$One $4s$ electron and one $3d$ electron
- C. $\hspace{1em}$Two $4s$ electrons
- D. $\hspace{1em}$Two $3d$ electrons
markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
$\ce{Cu}$ has the electron configuration $\ce{[Ar]}\, 4s^1\,3d^{10}$ (a full d-subshell is more stable). The $4s$ electron is lost in the first ionization followed by a $3d$ electron.

title: Question 40
content:
How many unpaired electrons are in the $\ce{Mn^{2+}}$ ion?


- A.$\hspace{1em}$5
- B.$\hspace{1em}$3
- C.$\hspace{1em}$1
- D.$\hspace{1em}$2
markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation:}}$
Manganese atoms have 25 electrons and have the electron configuration
Mn: $1s^2 2s^2 2p^6 3s^2 3p^6 4s^2 3d^5$
according to the aufbau principle.  When transition metals lose electrons, they lose them from the sublevel with the highest $n-$level.  For Mn, the two electrons are lost from the $4s$ sublevel to form the ion $\ce{Mn^2+}$.
$\ce{Mn^{2+}}$: $1s^2 2s^2 2p^6 3s^2 3p^6 3d^5$
To determine the number of unpaired electrons, we can draw the orbital box diagram and use Hund's law which maximizes the number of unpaired electrons in partially filled sublevels.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/e265c959-7bc9-4194-ba46-8554199f8bb3/images/9a9bc6c8-e8b3-49c5-af73-68b3320ed6a3/CH0777.png)


There are five unpaired electrons in the $\ce{Mn^{2+}}$ ion.

title: Question 43
content:
Which of the following best explains why dark lines appear in the following spectrum?
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/a5365ef0-5209-4ec6-ac9b-a2122f77697a/images/9e7287da-5026-4ca4-8933-7137e113e049/CH2145.png)




- A. $\hspace{1em}$Photons of specific energies are emitted as electrons fall to lower energy levels.
- B. $\hspace{1em}$Photons of specific energies are absorbed as electrons are excited to higher energy levels.
- C. $\hspace{1em}$Photons of specific energies are absorbed as electrons fall to lower energy levels.
- D. $\hspace{1em}$Photons of specific energies are emitted as electrons are excited to higher energy levels.
markScheme:
B

$\textrm{\underline{Explanation:}}$
Dark lines in an absorption spectrum are caused by electrons in atoms absorbing photons of specific energies. These energies correspond to the difference between allowed energy levels in the atom. When atoms absorb those photons, the electrons are excited to higher energy levels, and the absorbed wavelengths are missing from the observed spectrum, creating dark lines.
Some answers might seem tempting but are incorrect. For example, photons are not emitted when electrons are excited because energy must be absorbed for an electron to move to a higher level. Likewise, when electrons fall to lower energy levels, they emit photons, which is how emission spectra are formed. Suggesting that photons are absorbed while electrons fall is inaccurate, since falling to a lower energy level releases energy rather than requiring it.

title: Question 44
content: Magnesium is a combustible metal that is used in fireworks. - State the electron configuration for magnesium metal atom. [1] - When magnesium is exposed to hydrogen gas, it forms magnesium hydride. State the chemical formula for magnesium hydride and the oxidation state of each element in this compound. [2] Chemical formula: ________ Oxidation state of magnesium: ________ Oxidation state of hydrogen: ________ - Magnesium can be found in magnesium hydroxide, $\ce{Mg(OH)2}.$ State the type(s) of bonds present in magnesium hydroxide. [1] - Deduce the balanced chemical equation, including state symbols, for the combustion of magnesium metal. [1] - If $2.1\,\text{g}$ of magnesium and $1.5\,\text{dm}^3$ of $\ce{O2}$ were combusted at STP, calculate the mass of product formed. [3] - Magnesium reacts with hydrochloric acid, HCl, according to the following equation: $\ce{Mg(s) + 2 HCl(aq) <=> MgCl2(aq) + H2(g)}$ Calculate the molar enthalpy of reaction in $\text{kJ mol}^{-1}$ for Mg if $0.62\,\text{g}$ of Mg reacts with $120.0\,\text{g}$ of $0.8\,\text{mol dm}^{-3}$ HCl, resulting in a change of temperature from $21.0\,{}^\circ \text{C}$ to $39.8\,{}^\circ \text{C}$ in a calorimeter. [2]
markScheme:
- $1s^2 2s^2 2p^6 3s^2$ $\checkmark$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
Magnesium is in the $s$ block of the periodic table. Therefore, its valence shell is a set of $s$ orbitals. Since magnesium is in the third row of the periodic table, its outermost orbital is a $3s$, resulting in the electron configuration of $1s^2 2s^2 2p^6 3s^2$.
- Chemical formula: MgH$_2$ 
Oxidation state of magnesium: +2 $\checkmark$ 
Oxidation state of hydrogen: $-$1 $\checkmark$
Award M1 for 1 correct answer and M2 for 3 correct answers; 
Do not accept 2+ and 1$-$ for the oxidation states.
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
Metals have low electronegativity and will always have a positive charge in compounds.
  Hydrogen atoms will always have a +1 oxidation state unless bonded as hydride, in which case, hydrogen will have a $-1$ oxidation state.
  The chemical formula for magnesium hydride is determined by using the common charge for magnesium $(+2),$ requiring two hydrogen atoms with a $-1$ oxidation state to balance out the overall charge on the compound.
- ionic and (polar) covalent $\checkmark$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
Magnesium ion and hydroxide ion are bonded ionically due to the electrostatic attraction of opposite charges $(\ce{Mg^{2+}}$ and $\ce{OH^-}).$
  The $\ce{O-H}$ bond is covalent within hydroxide due to the closer similarity in electronegativity in the bonded atoms. This bond would be considered polar covalent since oxygen is much more electronegative than hydrogen.
- 2 Mg(s)  +  O$_2$(g) $\longrightarrow$ 2 MgO(s) $\checkmark$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
In a combustion reaction, the material being combusted is combined with oxygen. In this case, the magnesium reacts with oxygen gas in a synthesis reaction, forming magnesium oxide (MgO).
- Mg is the limiting reagent $\checkmark$ 
0.086 mol MgO $\checkmark$ 
3.5 g MgO $\checkmark$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
Since the quantities of both reactants are provided in this question, the limiting reagent must be determined as this will dictate the quantity of product:
  $n_{\text{O}_2} = 1.5\,\text{dm}^3 \times \dfrac{1\,\text{mol}}{22.7\,\text{dm}^3} = 0.066\,\text{mol}$ $n_\ce{Mg} = 2.1 \textrm{\ g} \times \dfrac {1\textrm{\ mol}}{24.31 \textrm{\ g}} = 0.086\textrm{\ mol}$
  If O$_2$ is the limiting reagent, then it would need to react with $0.066\textrm{\ mol} \ce{\ O_2} \times \dfrac {2\textrm{\ mol Mg}}{1\textrm{\ mol\ } \ce{O}_2} = 0.132 \textrm{\ mol Mg}$
  Since there is only 0.086 mol of Mg present, $\ce{O_2}$ cannot be the limiting reactant. Therefore, Mg is the limiting reactant, so we use stoichiometry to convert the 0.086 mol Mg into the moles of MgO formed:
  $n_\ce{MgO} = 0.086 \textrm{\ mol\ Mg} \times \dfrac {2 \textrm{\ mol Mg}}{2 \textrm{\ mol\ } \ce{MgO}} = 0.086 \textrm{\ mol MgO}$ $m_\ce{MgO} = 0.086 \textrm{\ mol MgO} \times \dfrac{40.31 \textrm{\  g}}{1 \textrm{\ mol}} = 3.5 \textrm{\ g MgO}$
- $q_{solution} = 9.43 \textrm{\ kJ} \: \checkmark$ 
$\Delta H = -370 \textrm{\ kJ mol}^{-1} \: \checkmark$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
This is a calorimetry question that requires the use of the formulas:
  $q_{solution} = mc\Delta T$
$q_{reaction}= -q_{solution}$
$\Delta H = \dfrac {q_{reaction}}{n}$
  where $q_{solution}$ is the heat absorbed by the solution as measured by the thermometer, $q_{reaction}$ is the heat lost during the exothermic chemical reaction, $c$ is the specific heat capacity of the solution, $m$ is the mass of the solution and $\Delta T$ is the change in temperature.
  Importantly, the student must assume that $0.8 \textrm{\ mol dm}^{-3}$ HCl has a specific heat capacity equal to that of water since it is aqueous $(4.18 \textrm{\ J g}^{-1}\textrm{\ K}^{-1}).$
  Also essential to answering this question, is that the mass is equal only to that of the HCl solution and does not include the mass of magnesium (essentially because the temperature change is being measured in the solution, not on the metal):
  $q_{solution} = 120.0\textrm{\  g} \times 4.18 \textrm{\ J g}^{-1} {^\circ} \textrm{C}^{-1}\times(39.8 - 21.0){^\circ}\textrm{C} = 9430.08 \textrm{\ J}$ 
$q_{reaction} = -9430.08 \textrm{\ J} \Rightarrow -9.43 \textrm{\ kJ}$
  To find the enthalpy change of the reaction, first determine the moles that reacted:
  $n_{Mg} = 0.620 \textrm{\ g Mg} \times \dfrac{1 \textrm{\ mol Mg}}{24.31 \textrm{\ g Mg}} = 0.0255 \textrm{\ mol}$
  Then the enthalpy changes is
  $\Delta H = \dfrac{-9.43 \textrm{\ kJ}}{0.0255 \textrm{\ mol}} = -370 \textrm{\ kJ mol}^{-1}$
  $\ $

title: Question 45
content:
Which statement(s) is(are) correct for chromium?


- I.$\hspace{1.em}$The electron configuration for its divalent cation is $\ce{[Ar]}3d^5.$
- II.$\hspace{0.7em}$It belongs to the $d-$block.
- III.$\hspace{0.4em}$Its condensed electronic configuration is $\ce{[Ar]}4s^2\,3d^4.$



- A.$\hspace{1em}$I and II only
- B.$\hspace{1em}$II only
- C.$\hspace{1em}$II and III only
- D.$\hspace{1em}$III only
markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation:}}$
