Neutral chromium has the observed ground$-$state configuration $\ce{[Ar]}4s^1 \,3d^5$ (the $4s$ and $3d$ subshells are very close in energy, and the $4s^1 \,3d^5$
arrangement is lower in energy than $4s^2 \, 3d^4$ for the atom). Statement III is false.
When chromium cations form, the $4s$ electrons are removed before the $3d$ electrons (electrons are removed from the highest $n$ level). For $\ce{Cr^{2+}},$ the electron configuration is $\ce{[Ar]}3d^4.$ Statement I is false.
With its highest$-$energy electrons in the $3d$ subshell, chromium belongs to the $d-$block transition metals.  Its placement in the periodic table supports this assessment.  Statement II is true.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/3984ad5b-c9b4-4c1f-b0cd-bb001f4e6c5c/images/661f93f8-2ee6-44fe-9c0f-89c979cd5c80/CH1222.png)

title: Question 47
content:
Which of the following statements about electron spin is correct?


- I.Unpaired electrons occupy separate orbitals within a sublevel before pairing occurs.II.Two electrons in the same orbital must have parallel spins.III.Spin is an intrinsic property of electrons that allows two electrons to occupy the same orbital.



- A. $\hspace{1em}$I and II
- B. $\hspace{1em}$II and III
- C. $\hspace{1em}$I and III
- D. $\hspace{1em}$I, II and III
markScheme:
C

$\textrm{\underline{Explanation:}}$
According to Hund's Rule, electrons fill orbitals of the same sublevel singly and with parallel spins before any pairing occurs. This minimizes electron-electron repulsion and leads to a more stable, lower-energy configuration. Statement I is correct.
Electrons in the same orbital must have opposite spins, not parallel spins, to satisfy the Pauli Exclusion Principle, which prevents two electrons in the same orbital from having identical properties. Statement II is incorrect.
Spin is an intrinsic property of electrons that allows them to share an orbital, as long as their spins are opposite ($\uparrow$ and $\downarrow$). This difference in spin enables two electrons to occupy the same spatial region without violating exclusion rules. Statement III is correct.

content:

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/59852886-12f9-4f0c-bdd6-5e47eba81474/images/7c0c049f-08ed-4e79-9e02-d3174160b738/CH1154B.png)


[Â© Revision Village 2023]
Transition D is the one with the greatest energy emission and the one with the greatest frequency.
This question is categorized as medium difficulty as students must recall the energy level diagram of hydrogen and compare different emissions.

title: Question 49
content:
Which of the following correctly describes the electron configuration of the $\ce{Ca^2+}$ ion?


- Number of occupied $p$ sublevelsNumber of occupied $p$ orbitalsA.$\hspace{1em}$26B.212C.62D.122
markScheme:
A

$\textrm{\underline{Explanation:}}$
In the $\ce{Ca^2+}$ ion, the electron configuration is $1s^2\ 2s^2\ 2p^6\ 3s^2\ 3p^6.$ This means that two $p$ sublevels are occupied: $2p$ and $3p.$ Each of these sublevels includes three $p$ orbitals, and in this case, all six $p$ orbitals are fully occupied. Understanding the distinction between sublevels and orbitals is essential to interpreting electron configurations accurately.

title: Question 50
content:
Which electron transition in the hydrogen atom emission spectrum emits radiation with the highest frequency?


- A. $\hspace{1em}n=1\longrightarrow n=7$
- B. $\hspace{1em}n=7 \longrightarrow n=1$
- C. $\hspace{1em}n=5 \longrightarrow n=2$
- D. $\hspace{1em}n=4 \longrightarrow n=3$
markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
To answer this question, students must differentiate emission (electrons decaying to a lower energy level) from absorption (electrons promoted to higher energy levels).
Students should also recall the relationship between frequency and energy ($E \propto f$). The highest frequency corresponds to the highesy energy transition.  According to the Bohr model, thediscrete energy levels in the hydrogen spectrum converge at higher energies. Of the three emissions proposed, the one with the greatest frequency/energy is $n=7 \longrightarrow n=1.$
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/89299878-7c02-447d-9568-fe86fcf00643/images/1fae25df-afde-432d-9d9e-b4c45710afca/CH0994.JPEG)


This question is categorized as hard as students compare transitions based on their knowledge of the hydrogen energy level diagram.

title: Question 1
content:
Which of the following statements does $\textbf{not}$ conform to the definition of a mole?


- A.$\hspace{1em}$ 1 mole is the number of H$_{2}$O molecules in 18.02 g of H$_{2}$O
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ 1 mole of Fe has a mass equal to the relative atomic mass of Fe in grams
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ 1 mole of any substance contains 6.02 $\times$ 10$^{23}$ particles
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ 1 mole is the number of H$_{2}$ molecules in 1.01 g of $\ce{H2}$
markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
1 mole is the number of $\ce{H_{2}}$ molecules in 2.02 g of $\ce{H_{2}}$. Choices A, B, and C all conform to the definition of a mole.

title: Question 2
content:
A mass spectrometer was used to determine that the relative ratio by mass of N : O in a molecule containing nitrogen and oxygen is $7 : 16.$ What is the most likely molecule?


- A.$\hspace{1em}\ce{NO}$
- B.$\hspace{1em}\ce{NO2}$
- C.$\hspace{1em}\ce{NO3}$
- D.$\hspace{1em}\ce{N2O5}$
markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$
Mass ratio is $7:16$ or $14:32$ so it must be $\ce{NO2}.$
Alternatively, assume 7 g N and 16 g O, and convert to moles.  Use the molar ratio to deduce the empirical formula.

title: Question 3
content:
Which compound has the largest molar mass?


- A.$\hspace{1em}$ $\ce{FeSO4}$
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ $\ce{K2Cr2O7}$
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ $\ce{KMnO4}$
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ $\ce{(NH4)3PO4}$
markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
M($\ce{K2Cr2O7}$) = (2)( 39.10) + (2)( 52) + (7)(16) = $294.2\,\text{g}\, \text{mol}^{-1}$ The other compounds have lower molar masses compared to $\ce{K2Cr2O7}$.
$\ce{FeSO4}$ ($151.9\,\text{g}\, \text{mol}^{-1}$), $\ce{KMnO4}$ ($158\,\text{g}\, \text{mol}^{-1}$), $\ce{(NH4)3PO4}$ ($149.1\,\text{g}\, \text{mol}^{-1}$)

title: Question 4
content:
Which of the following statements is true?


- A.$\hspace{1em}$ The empirical formula shows only the type of each atom in a molecule.
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ The molecular formula is always the same as the empirical formula.
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ Organic molecules often have different empirical and molecular formulas.
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ The empirical formula is always greater than the molecular formula.
markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
The empirical formula shows the simplest whole-number ratio of elements in a compound. The empirical formula can sometimes be the same as the molecular formula. Choices A, B, and D are all false statements.

title: Question 7
content:
Which of the following substances would have the lowest mass?


- A.$\hspace{1em}$ 2.50 moles  $\ce{H2O}$
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ 2.50 moles  $\ce{CH4}$
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ 2.00 moles $\ce{SO2}$
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ 2.00 moles $\ce{CO2}$
markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
$\ce{m(CH_4)} = n \times M = (2.50\,\text{mol})(16.05\,\text{g}\,\text{mol}^{-1}) = 40.1\,\text{g}$
The other compounds would have a greater mass.
$\ce{m(H2O)} = (2.50\,\text{mol})(18.02\,\text{g}\,\text{mol}^{-1}) = 45.05\,\text{g}$
$\ce{m(SO2)} = (2.00\,\text{moles})(64.07\,\text{g}\,\text{mol}^{-1}) = 128.14\,\text{g}$
$\ce{m(CO2)} = (2.00\,\text{moles})(44.01\,\text{g}\,\text{mol}^{-1}) =88.02\,\text{g}$

title: Question 9
content:
How many molecules are there in 4.80 mol of glucose?


- A.$\hspace{1em}$ 2.89 $\times$ 10$^{24}$ molecules
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ 2.50 $\times$ 10$^{24}$ molecules
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ 3.50 $\times$ 10$^{24}$ molecules
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ 2.59 $\times$ 10$^{24}$ molecules
markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Use Avogadro's number to interconvert the number of molecules to the amount of molecules in moles:
$N = n \times N_{A}$ $N = 4.80\,\textrm{mol} \times \dfrac{6.02 \times 10^{23}\,\textrm{molecules}}{1\,\textrm{mol}}$ = 2.89 $\times$ 10$^{24}\,\text{molecules}$

title: Question 11
content:
What is the total number of ions in 5.83 g of $\ce{Mg(OH)2}?$
$\mbox{}\\[-15pts]$
$M_r$ of $\ce{Mg(OH)2} = 58.3$ $N_A = 6.0\times 10^{23}\text{\ mol}^{-1}$


- A.$\hspace{1em}0.60 \times 10^{23}$
- B.$\hspace{1em}1.8 \times 10^{23}$
- C.$\hspace{1em}1.2 \times 10^{23}$
- D.$\hspace{1em}6.0 \times 10^{23}$
markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
First, we need to find moles of $\ce{Mg(OH)2}$ in 5.83 g:
$n_\ce{Mg(OH)2} = \dfrac{m}{M}$ $n_\ce{Mg(OH)2}= \dfrac{5.83\text{\ g}}{58.3\text{\ g mol}^{-1}} = 0.100\text{\ mol}$
To find the total number of ions in 0.100 moles of $\ce{Mg(OH)2},$ we need to consider the formula of $\ce{Mg(OH)2}$ and then calculate the number of ions it dissociates into when dissolved in water. The formula of magnesium hydroxide, $\ce{Mg(OH)2},$ suggests that each formula unit contains one magnesium ion, $\ce{Mg^2+},$ and two hydroxide ions, $\ce{OH-}.$ Since $\ce{Mg(OH)2}$ dissociates into one magnesium ion and two hydroxide ions per formula unit, we have 0.100 moles of magnesium $\ce{Mg^2+}$ ions and 0.200 moles of hydroxide $\ce{OH-}$ ions.
To find the total number of ions, we need to multiply these quantities by Avogadro's number:
$N = n N_A$ $N_\ce{Mg^2+} = (0.100\text{\ mol})(6.0\times 10^{23}\text{\ mol}^{-1}) = 0.60\times 10^{23}\text{\ ions }\ce{Mg^2+}$ $N_\ce{OH-} = (0.200\text{\ mol})(6.0\times 10^{23}\text{\ mol}^{-1}) = 1.2\times 10^{23}\ \ce{ions OH-}$
Adding the two numbers together gives us the answer $1.8\times 10^{23}$ which is option B.

title: Question 13
content:
To make a stock solution of aluminum nitrate $\ce{(Al(NO3)3},$ $M_r = 213.00)$, 10.65 g is dissolved in 150 cm$^3$ of water.
Which calculation below is used to determine the volume, in dm$^3$, of the stock solution needed to make 1.0 dm$^3$ of a 0.050 mol dm$^{-3}$ aluminum nitrate solution?


- A. $\hspace{1em}$ $\dfrac{10.65 \times 1 \times 0.050}{213.00 \times 0.150}$
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ $\dfrac{10.65}{213.00 \times 0.050 \times 1 \times 0.150}$
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ $\dfrac{0.050 \times 213.00 \times 0.150}{  10.65}$
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ $\dfrac{213.0 \times 0.050}{10.65 \times 1 \times 0.150}$
markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation:}}$
First, find the concentration of the stock solution, $C_1$.
$C = \dfrac{n}{V}$ $n = \dfrac{10.65\,\text{g}}{213.00\,\text{g mol}^{-1}}; \hspace{0.2in} V = 0.150\,\text{dm}^3$ $C_1 = \dfrac{10.65}{213.00 \times 0.150}\,\text{mol dm}^{-3}$
For dilutions, we can use the formula
$C_1V_1 = C_2V_2$
which relies on the number of moles in the concentrated stock solution being equal to the number of moles in the dilute, 1.0 mol dm$^3$ solution.
Rearranging to find the volume of the stock solution required, $V_1$,
$V_1 = \dfrac{C_2 \times  V_2}{C_1}$
We are given that $C_2 = 0.050\,\text{mol dm}^{-3}$ and $V_2 = 1.0\,\text{dm}^3.$  Plugging these values in to the expression for $V_1,$ along with the $C_1$ found above, gives
$V_1 = \dfrac{0.050\,\text{mol dm}^{-3}\times 1.0\,\text{dm}^3}{\frac{10.65}{213.00\times 0.150}\,\text{mol dm}^{-3}}$ $V_1 = \dfrac{0.050\times 1.0\times 213.00\times 0.150}{10.65}\,\text{dm}^3$

title: Question 16
content:
0.0400 moles of magnesium nitrate $\ce{Mg(NO3)2}$ is dissolved in 500 cm$^3$ of water. What is the resulting concentration of all ions in solution?


- A. $\hspace{1em}0.240 \textrm{\ mol dm}^{-3}$
- B. $\hspace{1em}0.0600 \textrm{\ mol dm}^{-3}$
- C. $\hspace{1em}0.160 \textrm{\ mol dm}^{-3}$
- D. $\hspace{1em}0.120 \textrm{\ mol dm}^{-3}$
markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation:}}$
When magnesium nitrate is placed in water it completely dissolves to form its ions:
$\ce{Mg(NO3)2 -> Mg^{2+} + 2 NO3-}$
If the initial amount of magnesium nitrate was 0.0400 mol, the ions will appear in a $1:2$ ratio, 0.0400 mol $\ce{Mg^{2+}}$ and 0.0800 mol $\ce{NO3-}$.  The total amount of ions is sum, $0.0400 + 0.0800 = 0.1200 \textrm{ mol}.$
To find the concentration, use the relationship $C = \dfrac{n}{V}$.  The units of volume must be converted from cm$^3$ to dm$^3$, so we can use the relationship $1000\,\text{cm}^3 = 1\,\text{dm}^3.$
$C = \dfrac{n}{V} = \dfrac{0.1200 \textrm{\ mol}}{500 \textrm{\ cm}^3} \times \dfrac{1000 \textrm{\ cm}^3}{1 \textrm{\ dm}^3} = 0.240\,\text{mol dm}^{-3}$

title: Question 17
content: Ascorbic acid ($\ce{C6H8O6}$), or vitamin C, is a water-soluble vitamin that is essential for our immune system. - Calculate the number of moles in $2.50\,\textrm{g}$ of ascorbic acid. [1] - Calculate the mass of $1.28\,\textrm{moles}$ of ascorbic acid. [1] - Calculate the number of molecules in $50.0\,\textrm{g}$ of ascorbic acid. [2] - Determine the number of moles of carbon in $225\,\textrm{mg}$ of ascorbic acid [2]
markScheme:
- $n = \dfrac{m}{M} = \dfrac{2.50\,\textrm{g}}{176.14\,\textrm{g}\,\text{mol}^{-1}}$ = $0.0142\,\text{mol}$ $\checkmark$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}$
  Molar mass of ascorbic acid. $M(\ce{C6H8O6}) = (12.01)(6) + (1.01) (8) + (16.00)(6) = 72.06 + 8.08 + 96.00 = 176.14\,\text{g}\,\text{mol}^{-1}$
- $m = n\times M = (1.28\,\text{mol}) (176.14\,\text{g}\,\text{mol}^{-1})$ = $225\,\text{g}$ $\checkmark$
  $\textit {ALLOW error carried forward from incorrect }$M(C$_{6}$H$_{8}$O$_{6}$) $\textit {calculation in (a)}$
- Number of moles of ascorbic acid in 50.0 grams:
  n = $\dfrac{m}{M} = \dfrac{50.0\,\text{g}}{176.14\,\text{g}\,\text{mol}^{-1}}$ = $0.284\,\text{mol}$ $\checkmark$
  Number of molecules:
  $N = n\times N_A = (0.284\,\text{mol})(6.02\times 10^{23})$ = $1.71\times 10^{23}$ molecules $\checkmark$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}$
  $N_A$ is Avogadro's number given in the data booklet.
- Number of moles in 225 $\textit{mg}$ of ascorbic acid:
  $n = \dfrac{m}{M} = \dfrac{0.225\,\text{g}}{176.14\,\text{g}\,\text{mol}^{-1}}$ = $1.277\times 10^{-3}\,\text{mol}$ ascorbic acid $\checkmark$
  Number of moles of carbon:
  $(0.001277\,\text{mol}\ce{C6H8O6})\left(\dfrac{6\,\text{mol}\,\text{C}}{1\,\text{mol}\,\ce{C6H8O6}}\right)$ = $0.00766\,\text{mol}$ C $\checkmark$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}$
  There are 6 moles of carbon in every mole of ascorbic acid. Therefore, multiplying the moles of ascorbic acid by 6 results in obtaining the moles of carbon.

title: Question 21
content:
Which is the correct empirical formula for a compound that is composed of 40% sulfur and 60% oxygen by mass?


- A. $\hspace{1em}\ce{SO}$
- B. $\hspace{1em}\ce{S2O3}$
- C. $\hspace{1em}\ce{SO2}$
- D. $\hspace{1em}\ce{SO3}$
markScheme:
D

$\textrm{\underline{Explanation:}}$
To determine the empirical formula from a mass % composition, first we assume that the sample is 100 g so that the percent composition can be easily converted to mass:
40% sulfur $\longrightarrow$ 40 g sulfur
60% oxygen $\longrightarrow$ 60 g oxygen
Next, these masses are converted into moles:
$40\text{ g S}\times \dfrac{1\text{ mol}}{32\text{ g}} = 1.25\text{ mol S}$ $60\text{ g O}\times \dfrac{1\text{ mol}}{16\text{ g}} = 3.75\text{ mol O}$
From here, the ratio between the atoms is determined:
$\dfrac{\text{mol O}}{\text{mol S}} = \dfrac{3.75\text{ mol}}{1.25\text{ mol}} = 3$
Therefore, there are 3 atoms of oxygen for every 1 atom of sulfur so the empirical formula is $\ce{SO3}.$

title: Question 24
content:
What mass of lead (II) carbonate would contain $20.7\, \textrm{g}$ of lead?


- A.$\hspace{1em} 47.4\, \textrm{g}$
- B.$\hspace{1em} 26.7\, \textrm{g}$
- C.$\hspace{1em} 23.5\, \textrm{g}$
- D.$\hspace{1em} 32.7\, \textrm{g}$
markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The molar mass of lead is $207.2 \textrm{\ g mol}^{-1},$ so there is about 0.1 mol Pb. Lead (II) carbonate, $\ce{PbCO3},$ contains 1 atom of lead for every formula unit of lead (II) carbonate: there must be 0.1 mol $\ce{PbCO3}.$ The molar mass of lead carbonate is $267.2 \textrm{\ g mol}^{-1},$ so there are 26.7 g.

title: Question 25
content: A sample of $9.70\,\text{g}$ of an unknown organic compound composed of carbon, hydrogen, and nitrogen was burnt with excess oxygen. The combustion produced nitrogen gas, $27.5\,\text{g}$ of $\ce{CO2}$ and $6.57\,\text{g}$ of $\ce{H2O}$. - Calculate the mass of nitrogen produced. [3] - Determine the empirical formula of the compound. [2]
markScheme:
- Mass of carbon produced:
  $n_C = \dfrac{m}{M} = \dfrac{27.5\,\text{g}}{44.01\,\text{g}\,\text{mol}^{-1}} = 0.624\,\text{mol}$
  $m_C = (0.624\,\text{mol})(12.01\,\text{g}\,\text{mol}^{-1}) =$ $7.49\,\text{g}$ $\checkmark$
  Mass of hydrogen produced:
  $n_H = 2\,\dfrac{m}{M} = 2\,\dfrac{6.57\,\text{g}}{18.02\,\text{g}\,\text{mol}^{-1}} = 0.729\,\text{mol}$
  $m_H = (0.729\,\text{mol})(1.01\,\text{g}\,\text{mol}^{-1}) =$ $0.736\,\text{g}$ $\checkmark$
  Mass of nitrogen produced:
  $m_N = 9.70 - (7.49 + 0.736) =$ $1.46\,\text{g}$ $\checkmark$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}$
  There is one mole of carbon atoms in every mole of carbon dioxide produced. The number of moles of carbon dioxide are therefore equal to the number of moles of carbon in the original unknown compound.
  There are two moles of hydrogen atoms in every mole of water produced. The number of  moles of water therefore must be multiplied by 2 to give the number of  moles of H atoms in the original compound.
  The mass of nitrogen in the organic compound is the same as the mass of nitrogen after combustion due to conservation of mass and can therefore be calculate by subtracting the masses of C and H from the total mass of the unknown organic compound.
- $n_N = \dfrac{1.46\,\text{g}}{14.01\,\text{g}\,\text{mol}^{-1}} =$ $0.104\,\text{mol}$
  Divide the number of moles of each element by the smallest mole value $\checkmark$
  For C:  $\dfrac{0.624}{0.104} = 6$
  For H:  $\dfrac{0.729}{0.104} = 7$
  For N:  $\dfrac{0.104}{0.104} = 1$
  The empirical formula of the compound is $\ce{C6H7N}$ $\checkmark$

title: Question 26
content:
What is the concentration of sodium ions in a $0.356 \textrm{\ mol dm}^{-3}$ solution of sodium sulfate?


- A.$\hspace{1em}$0.356
- B.$\hspace{1em}$0.712
- C.$\hspace{1em}$0.425
- D.$\hspace{1em}$0.850
markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Sodium sulfate ($\ce{Na2SO4}$) dissociates in water, releasing two sodium cations.
$[\ce{Na+}] = 2\times 0.356\,\text{mol dm}^{-3} = 0.712\,\text{mol dm}^{-3}$
This question is categorized as medium difficulty, requiring students to deduce the molecular formula of sodium sulfate and the cation concentration in an aqueous solution.

title: Question 27
content: A student carried out an experiment to determine the empirical formula of an oxide of manganese. $3.60\,\text{g}$ of the metal was heated in the presence of an excess of oxygen. When the metal reacted completely, $5.64\,\text{g}$ of metal oxide were formed. - Deduce the empirical formula of the oxide. [3] - Suggest an experimental technique the student can use to ensure that the manganese has completely reacted. [1] - A common impurity in manganese is carbon. How would this impurity affect the determination of the empirical formula? [2]
markScheme:
- $m_\ce{O2} = 5.64 - 3.60 = 2.04\,\text{g}\ \checkmark$
  $n_\ce{Mn} = 0.0655$ AND $n_\ce{O2} = 0.128\ \checkmark$
  $\ce{MnO2}\ \checkmark$
  Award full marks for correct final answer.
  $\textrm{\underline{Further Explanation:}}$
  The mass of oxygen can be obtained by subtracting the mass of the metal from the mass of the metal oxide.
  $m_\ce{Mn_xO_y} - m_\ce{Mn} = m_\ce{O}$ $5.62\,\text{g} - 3.60\,\text{g} = 2.02\,\text{g}$
  The moles for each of the elements can be obtained by applying the formula; $n = \dfrac{m}{M}$.
  $n_\ce{Mn} = \dfrac{3.60\,\text{g}}{54.94\,\text{g mol}^{-1}} = 0.0655\,\text{mol}$ $n_\ce{O} = \dfrac{2.04\,\text{g}}{16.00\,\text{g mol}^{-1}} = 0.128\,\text{mol}$
  The simplest ratio is obtained by dividing the moles of the substance by the smallest value of moles. This is the empirical formula:
  
  
  - Mn: $\dfrac{0.0655\,\text{mol}}{0.0655\,\text{mol}} = 1$
  - O: $\dfrac{0.128\,\text{mol}}{0.0655\,\text{mol}} = 1.95\approx 2$

  The empirical formula is $\ce{MnO2}$.
- Repeatedly heat and weigh until constant mass is achieved $\checkmark$
  $\textrm{\underline{Further Explanation:}}$
  The mass of the sample is considered to have reached a constant value when the difference between successive weighings is minimal and falls within an acceptable range of experimental error. This indicates that all of the manganese has reacted with oxygen within practical restrictions.
- more oxygen will react per unit mass (to form $\ce{CO2})\,\checkmark$
  the ratio of O to Mn will be greater than 2 $\checkmark$
  $\textrm{\underline{Further Explanation:}}$
  If the manganese sample contains carbon as an impurity, it will also react with oxygen to form carbon dioxide. The additional mass of oxygen bonded to carbon would be incorrectly attributed to the formation of the manganese oxide. This would result in an overestimation of the oxygen content in the final product and an artificially high oxygen-to-manganes ratio. Consequently, the empirical formula of the manganese oxide would be determined incorrectly, potentially showing a higher number of oxygen atoms per manganese atom than is accurate (e.g., $\ce{MnO3}$ instead of $\ce{MnO2}).$

title: Question 29
content:
Water is added to  $200\,\text{cm}^3$ of a $1.50\times 10^{-3}\,\text{mol dm}^{-3}$ HCl solution. The resulting solution has a volume $300\,\text{cm}^3$ greater than the initial. Which statement is correct?


- A.$\hspace{1em}$The amount of solute remains constant, and the final concentration is $6.00\times 10^{-4}\,\text{mol dm}^{-3}.$
- B.$\hspace{1em}$The amount of solute remains constant, and the final concentration is $1.00\times 10^{-3}\,\text{mol dm}^{-3}.$
- C.$\hspace{1em}$The amount of solute decreases, and the final concentration is $6.00\times 10^{-4}\,\text{mol dm}^{-3}.$
- D.$\hspace{1em}$The amount of solute decreases, and the final concentration is $1.00\times 10^{-3}\,\text{mol dm}^{-3}.$
markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
This is a dilution problem. The key idea is that when solvent is added, the number of moles of solute stays the same while the total volume increases. First calculate the amount of solute in the original solution using $n = CV.$
$n = 1.50 \times 10^{-3} \textrm{\ mol dm}^{-3} \times 0.200 \textrm{\ dm}^3 = 3.00 \times 10^{-4} \textrm{\ mol}$
After adding $300,\text{cm}^3$ of water, the final volume is $200 + 300 = 500 \text{\ cm}^3 = 0.500 \text{\ dm}^3$.
The concentration of the diluted solution is therefore
$[\ce{HCl}] =  \dfrac{3.00 \times 10^{-4} \textrm{\ mol}}{0.500 \textrm{\ dm}^3} = \answer{6.00 \times 10^{-4} \textrm{\ mol dm}^{-3}}$

title: Question 3
content:
Based on the graph below, choose the correct statement that describes the relationship between pressure and temperature for a fixed mass and volume of a gas?
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/a5b7d708-dada-487b-9f1b-ee2fb3f45b47/images/02187be4-3809-445d-b70e-4ae6dde3de0d/1.3-36.png)




- A.$\hspace{1em}$Pressure is inversely proportional to the absolute temperature
- B.$\hspace{1em}$Pressure is directly proportional to the square of the absolute temperature
- C.$\hspace{1em}$Pressure is inversely proportional to the square of the absolute temperature
- D.$\hspace{1em}$Pressure is directly proportional to the absolute temperature
markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The graph of P vs T shows a linear graph (straight line passing through the origin) that rises upward. This graph shows that P is directly proportional to the absolute temperature. As the absolute temperature increases, the pressure of the gas also increases.

title: Question 4
content: The ideal gas equation is a formula that combines the relationship between pressure, volume, temperature, and the number of moles. - Complete the table below by calculating the missing variables of the ideal gas equation. [4] $\mathbf{P} $ $\mathbf{V}$ $\mathbf{n}$ $\mathbf{T}$(1)$\quad 0.015\,\textrm{m}^{3}\quad$ $0.400\,\textrm{mol}$ $37\,{}^\circ \mathrm{C}$ $\quad 152,000\,\textrm{Pa}\quad$(2)$2.00\,\textrm{mol}$ $\quad 298\,\textrm{K}\quad$ $31,000\,\textrm{Pa}$ $0.25\,\textrm{m}^{3}$(3)$271\,\textrm{K}$ $250\,\textrm{kPa}$ $0.75\,\textrm{dm}^{3}$ $\quad 0.580\,\textrm{mol}\quad$(4) - A $256\,\textrm{cm}^{3}$ flask contains $0.800\,\textrm{g}$ of a gaseous compound with an empirical formula of CHCl. The pressure and the temperature of the gas are respectively $1.00\times 10^{5}\,\textrm{Pa}$ and $373\,\textrm{K}$. Determine the molecular formula of the compound. [4]
markScheme:
- For (1): Use the ideal gas equation to calculate the pressure of the gas.
  $\begin{aligned}
  PV &= nRT \\[3pt]
  P &= \dfrac{nRT}{V} \\
  P &= \dfrac{(0.400\,\text{mol})(8.31\,\text{J K}^{-1}\,\text{mol}^{-1})(310\,\text{K})}{0.015\,\text{m}^{3}} = \answer{6.9\times 10^{4}\,\text{Pa}}\,  \checkmark
  \end{aligned}$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}$
  Temperature must be given in Kelvin.
  $T(\text{K}) = 37 + 273 = 310\,\text{K}$
  For (2): Use the ideal gas equation to calculate for the volume of the gas:
  $\begin{aligned}
  PV &= nRT \\
  V &= \dfrac{nRT}{P} \\
  V &= \dfrac{(2.00\,\text{mol})(8.31\,\text{J K}^{-1}\,\text{mol}^{-1})(298\,\text{K})}{152000\,\text{Pa}} = \answer{0.0326\,\textrm{m}^{3}}\, \checkmark
  \end{aligned}$
  For (3): Use the ideal gas equation to calculate for the number of moles of the gas.
  $\begin{aligned}
  PV &= nRT \\
  n &= \dfrac{PV}{RT} \\
  n &= \dfrac{(31000\,\text{Pa})(0.25\,\text{m}^{3})}{(8.31\,\text{J K}^{-1}\,\text{mol}^{-1})(271\,\text{K})} = \answer{3.4\,\textrm{mol}}\, \checkmark
  \end{aligned}$
  For (4): Use the ideal gas equation to calculate the temperature of the gas. Make sure that pressure is in Pascals and volume is in m$^{3}$.
  $\begin{aligned}
  PV &= nRT \\
  T &= \dfrac{PV}{nR} \\
  T &= \dfrac{(250000\,\text{Pa})(0.00075\,\text{m}^{3})}{(0.580\,\text{mol})(8.31\,\text{J K}^{-1}\,\text{mol}^{-1})} = \answer{39\,\text{K}}\, \checkmark
  \end{aligned}$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}$
  Volume must be given in m$^3$.
  $V = (0.75\,\text{dm}^3)\left(\dfrac{1\,\text{m}^3}{1000\,\text{dm}^3}\right) = 0.00075\,\text{m}^3$
- $M_{gas} = \dfrac{(0.800\,\text{g})(8.31\,\text{J K}^{-1}\,\text{mol}^{-1})(373\,\text{K})}{(1.00\times 10^{5}\,\text{Pa})(256\times 10^{-6}\,\text{m}^{3})} = \answer{96.9\,\text{g}\,\text{mol}^{-1}}\, \checkmark$
  $M_{\ce{CHCl}} = 12.01 + 1.01 + 35.45 = \answer{48.47\,\text{g}\,\text{mol}^{-1}}\, \checkmark$
  $\dfrac{96.9\textrm{\ g mol}^{-1}}{48.47\textrm{\ g mol}^{-1}}$ â 2 $\checkmark$
  The molecular formula is $\ce{C2H2Cl2}$ $\checkmark$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}$
  Step 1: Use the ideal gas equation to calculate the molar mass of the gas: $PV = nRT = \left(\dfrac{m}{M}\right)RT$
  Therefore, $M = \dfrac{mRT}{PV}$
  Step 2: Calculate the empirical formula molar mass.
  Step 3: Determine the molecular formula.

title: Question 5
content:
A sample of gas at the top of a mountain has a pressure of $75\text{ kPa}$ and a volume of $4.0\text{ dm}^3.$ If that same sample is brought to the bottom of the mountain where the pressure is now $100\text{ kPa},$ what is the new volume of the gas assuming that the temperature is kept constant?


- A. $\hspace{1em}0.75\text{ dm}^3$
- B. $\hspace{1em}0.19\text{ dm}^3$
- C. $\hspace{1em}3.0\text{ dm}^3$
- D. $\hspace{1em}5.3\text{ dm}^3$
markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation:}}$
This question is answered using the Ideal Gas Law equation, $PV = nRT.$ It is assumed that the moles of the gas are the same and the temperature remains constant, so we can set $PV$ for each scenario to be equal to each other:
$P_1V_1 = P_2V_2$
where

- $P_1V_1$ is  the pressure and volume at the top of the mountain
- $P_2V_2$ isthe pressure and volume at the bottom of the mountain

Rearranging,
$V_2 = \dfrac{P_1V_1}{P_2} = \dfrac{(75\text{ kPa})(4.0\text{ dm}^3)}{100\text{ kPa}} = \answer{3.0\text{ dm}^{3}}$

title: Question 7
content:
Based on the table below, what is the correct calculation to determine the final volume of a fixed mass of gas:

InitialFinalPressure (atm)1.001.60Temperature ($^\circ$C)2010Volume (dm$^3$)5.00?



- A.$\hspace{1em}$ $\dfrac{(1.00 \ \textrm{atm})(5.00 \  \textrm{dm}^3)(283 \ \textrm{K})}{(1.60\ \textrm{atm})(293\ \textrm{K})}$
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ $\dfrac{(1.00 \textrm{\ atm})(5.00 \ \textrm{dm}^3)(10 \ ^\circ\mathrm{C})}{(1.60 \textrm{\ atm})(20 \  ^\circ\mathrm{C})}$
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ $\dfrac{(1.60 \textrm{\ atm})(5.00\ \textrm{dm}^3)(20 ^\circ\mathrm{C})}{(1.00 \textrm{\ atm})(10 ^\circ\mathrm{C})}$
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ $\dfrac{(1.60 \textrm{\ atm})(5.00\ \textrm{dm}^3)(283\textrm{\ K})}{(1.00 \textrm{\ atm})(293\textrm{\ K})}$
markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Ideal gas equation: $PV= nRT$
The number of moles is the same since there is a fixed mass of gas, and R is a constant.
$P_1V_1= nRT_1$  and $P_2V_2 = nRT_2$
The temperature must be measured on the absolute scale, in K.
Using the combined gas law equation,
$\dfrac{P_1V_1}{T_1} = \dfrac{P_2V_2}{T_2}$
we can derive the expression:
$V_2 = \dfrac{P_1V_1T_2}{P_2T_1} = \dfrac{(1.00\,\text{atm})(5.00\,\text{dm}^3)(283\,\text{K})}{(1.60\,\text{atm})(293\,\text{K})}$
$10\,{}^\circ\mathrm{C} + 273 = 283\,\text{K}$
$20\,{}^\circ\mathrm{C} + 273 = 293\,\text{K}$

title: Question 9
content:
A sample of oxygen gas with volume $V_1$ is at pressure $1.00\times\ 10^5\,\text{Pa}$. At constant temperature, what is the pressure if $V_1$ is halved?


- A.$\hspace{1em}2.00\times 10^5\,\text{Pa}$
- B.$\hspace{1em}5.00\times 10^4\,\text{Pa}$
- C.$\hspace{1em}5.00\times 10^5\,\text{Pa}$
- D.$\hspace{1em}2.00\times 10^4\,\text{Pa}$
markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
According to Boyle's Law, at constant temperature:
$P_1V_1 = P_2V_2$
Rearranging,
$P_2 = \dfrac{P_1V_1}{V_2} = \dfrac{P_1V_1}{\frac{1}{2}V_1} = 2P_1$ $P_2 = \answer{2.00\times 10^5\,\text{Pa}}$

title: Question 11
content:
6.00 g of ethane gas $(M_r \approx 30)$ is placed in a flexible container at STP. The conditions are then changed to a new pressure of 200,000 Pa and a new temperature of 546 K.
What is the new volume of the container after equilibrating to the new temperature and pressure?
The molar volume of a gas at STP is 22.7 dm$^3$.


- A.$\hspace{1em}22.7\,\text{dm}^3$
- B.$\hspace{1em}2.27\,\text{dm}^3$
- C.$\hspace{1em}4.54\,\text{dm}^3$
- D.$\hspace{1em}9.08\,\text{dm}^3$
markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation:}}$
At STP, standard temperature and pressure, the pressure is 100 kPa (100,000 Pa) and the temperature is 0 $^\circ$C (273 K). A sample of ethane gas is taken from standard conditions and put into new conditions where the pressure is doubled (200000 kPa) and the temperature is doubled (546 K).
The amount of ethane is constant through the experiment:
$n_\ce{C2H6} = \dfrac{m}{M} = \dfrac{6.00\,\text{g}}{30\,\text{g mol}^{-1}} = 0.200\,\text{mol}$
Using the molar volume of a gas at STP, we can deduce the original volume of the gas:
$V_1 = n V_m = 0.200\,\text{mol}\times 22.7\,\text{dm}^3\,\text{mol}^{-1} = 4.54\,\text{dm}^3$
The final volume of the gas can be determined from the combined gas law:
$\dfrac{P_1V_1}{T_1} = \dfrac{P_2V_2}{T_2}$
Solving for $V_2$:
$V_2 = \dfrac{P_1V_1T_2}{T_1P_2}$;
Logically, the pressure $P_2$ and the temperature $T_2$ doubled, so the volume $V_2$ remains the same. Mathematically,
$V_2 = \dfrac{100000\,\text{Pa}\times 4.54\,\text{dm}^3\times 546\,\text{K}}{273\,\text{K}\times 200000\text{Pa}}$
The final volume of ethane is 4.54 dm$^3$.

title: Question 12
content:
A $500\,\text{cm}^3$ flask is weighed empty.  After a chemical reaction was conducted, a gas was collected at SATP conditions.  The flask was found to increase in mass by $1.43\,\text{g}.$ What is the name of the gas collected?


- A.$\hspace{1em}$Hydrogen
- B.$\hspace{1em}$Oxygen
- C.$\hspace{1em}$Carbon dioxide
- D.$\hspace{1em}$Chlorine
markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
At SATP conditions $(P = 100 \textrm{\ kPa}, T = 298.15 \textrm{\ K})$, the ideal gas law can be used to deduce the molar mass of the unknown gas. Starting from $PV=nRT,$ and substituting $n = \frac{m}{M},$ we obtain
$PV = \dfrac{mRT}{M}$
which rearranges to
$M = \dfrac{mRT}{PV}$
Converting the volume to $\textrm{dm}^3$ (because $1 \textrm{\ J} = 1 \textrm{\ kPa dm}^3),$ and substituting the given values
$M = \dfrac{1.43 \textrm{\ g} \times 8.31 \textrm{\ J mol}^{-1} \times 298.15 \textrm{\ K}}{\textrm{\ 100 \textrm kPa} \times {0.500 \textrm{\ dm}^3}} = 70.9 \textrm{\ g mol}^{-1}$
Comparing this value with the molar masses of the candidate gases we can identify the unknown: hydrogen $(\ce{H2}, \ 2.02 \textrm{\ g mol}^{-1}),$ oxygen $(\ce{O2},\ 32.00 \textrm{\ g mol}^{-1}),$ carbon dioxide $(\ce{CO2},\ 44.01 \textrm{\ g mol}^{-1}),$ and chlorine $(\ce{Cl2},\ 70.90 \textrm{\ g mol}^{-1}).$ The measured value corresponds to chlorine.
This is a challenging question because it requires students to combine experimental data with the ideal gas equation to infer an unknown identity, rather than relying on a direct recall of facts.

title: Question 16
content:
A sample of gas at a certain temperature, pressure, and volume ($T_1$, $P_1$, and $V_1$) undergoes a change in temperature and pressure ($T_2$ and $P_2$). What is the new volume ($V_2$)?


- 
  
  - Before: $T_1, P_1, V_1$
  - After:	$P_2 = 2P_1 \quad \textrm{AND} \quad T_2 = \frac{1}{2} T_1$




- A.$\hspace{1em}\frac{1}{2} V_1$
- B.$\hspace{1em}\frac{1}{8} V_1$
- C.$\hspace{1em}\frac{1}{4} V_1$
- D.$\hspace{1em}4V_1$
markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation:}}$
Use the combined gas law:
$\dfrac{P_1 V_1}{T_1}= \dfrac{P_2 V_2}{T_2}$ $V_2 =\dfrac{P_1 V_1 T_2}{T_1 P_2} =\dfrac{P_1 V_1 \ \frac{1}{2}T_1}{T_1\ 2P_1} =\dfrac{\frac{1}{2}V_1}{2} =$ $\frac{1}{4} V_1$
Alternate Method:
To answer this question, the student must understand and apply the relationships between temperature, pressure, and volume in the ideal gas model:
$PV = nRT$
Therefore, $V \propto T$ and $P \propto \dfrac{1}{V}$.
Since volume and temperature are directly proportional, an increase in one will result in an increase in the other at the same magnitude.
In this case, $T_2 = \frac{1}{2}  T_1$ resulting in $V_2 = \frac{1}{2} V_1$.
Pressure is doubled, but since volume and pressure are inversely proportional, this results in $V_2 = \frac{1}{2} V_1$.
Compounding these effects results in $V_2 = \frac{1}{4} V_1$.
This question is categorized as medium because it requires an understanding of the ideal gas law and proportionalities based on $PV = nRT$.
